To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, 17th December, 1913.

Sir:

I enclose herewith a requisition for drugs required for use at the Indian Industrial School, Spanish, Ont., and I have to request that you will kindly supply the same. The drugs should be pure and of the best quality and securely packed. They should be addressed to the Rev. L.N. Dugas, S.J., Principal of the Spanish River Industrial School, Spanish, Ont.

Your account in duplicate should be sent to the Principal of the School for his certificate, and for transmission by him to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary,

The Carlton Drug Store,
Wellington St.,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, 17th December, 1913.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your recent communication, I beg to say that the Carlton Drug Company of this city have been requested to ship to you the drugs for which you have made requisition for use in the Girls' School at Spanish River. Kindly make a note of the fact that all requisitions for drugs should be submitted in duplicate. The firm has been told to send their account in detail and in duplicate to you for your certificate. If the drugs are received by you in good order you should certify the account, and transmit to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. L.N. Dugas S.J.,
Principal,
Spanish River Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Ottawa 26th January, 1914.

Sir,

I enclose herewith a requisition for drugs required for use at the Indian Industrial School at Spanish River, Ont., and I have to request that you will kindly supply the same, and have them securely packed and shipped, with the least possible delay, to the Revd L.V. Dugas, Principal of the School. The drugs should be pure and of the best quality.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Mr. R. Perkins,
Druggist,
Elgin Street,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, 26th January, 1914.

Rev. Sir:

I beg to draw attention to letter to you of the 17th December, relative to drugs which the Carlton Drug Co. was requested to ship to you. The Department would be glad to know whether you received them in good order. If they reached you in satisfactory condition, it is desired that you will certify the company's account and forward it to the Department with a view to payment.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Aas. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. LeM. Dugas S.J.,
Principal, Spanish River Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.

To the Secretary Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter No. 388664-1 dated Jan. 25th I beg to say that I have certified all accounts for drugs received, and have sent them to the Dept. Re the Carlton Drug Co. we never received the drugs nor the accounts for them.

The drugs requested then as stated in the letter of the 17th of December were for the girls' school, we never received them.

Since that time we made a new requisition for cough medicine that we did not receive although they are badly needed.

I send in a new requisition for drugs including the above cough medicine and other drugs needed for the boys' school. Besides I will send you a duplicate of the requisition made for the girls' school for the drugs not received.

James Truax,
J.M. Rogers, Principal
Spanish River Ind. School.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Ottawa, 3rd February, 1914.

Rev. Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 31st ultimo, I beg to say that Mr. R. I. Harrison, druggist of this city, has been requested to ship to you the drugs for which you have made requisition in that letter with the exception of 1 gal. Coriaria Comp.; 1 gal. Wampole's Cod Liver Oil Comp. and 3 thermometers, which articles were ordered for your school from Mr. R. Perkins, and shipped recently. The Department is making inquiry of the Carlton Drug Company, with regard to the drugs ordered from that firm.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. L. V. Dugas, S.J.,
Principal,
Spanish River Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.

OTTAWA, 3rd February, 1914.

SIR,

I enclose herewith a list of drugs required for use at the Industrial Indian School at Spanish, Ont., and I have to request that you will kindly ship the articles in question, which should be pure and of the best quality and securely packed to the Principal of the School, the Rev. L.V. Dugas.

Your accounts in duplicate and in detail should be forwarded to the Principal, whose certificate thereto is required before the matter of payment can receive attention by the Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Mr. R. I. Harrison,
Druggist,
Cor. Rideau & Cumberland Sts.,
Ottawa, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Ottawa, 6th April, 1914.

Rev. Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 3rd instant, I beg to say that Mr. Jos. P. Valiquette, of this city, has been requested to supply the drugs for which you made requisition for use at the Industrial School at Spanish. He has been told that the drugs are to be pure and of the best quality, and they should be securely packed. If they reach you in good order, you should certify Mr. Valiquette's account and return it to the Department with a view to payment.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. L. V. Dugas, S.J.,
Principal,
Spanish River Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.
Ottawa, 6th April, 1914.

Sir:

I have to request that you will kindly supply the drugs mentioned on the list herewith enclosed for use at the Industrial Indian School at Spanish, Ont. The drugs should be pure and of the best quality and should be shipped to the Rev. L. V. Dugas, Principal, Spanish River Industrial School, Spanish, Ont. Kindly advise the principal of the date of shipment and send your account in triplicate to him, as his certificate thereto is required before payment can be considered by the Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Mr. Jos. P. Valiquette,
Drugist,
Cor. Clarence & Dalhousie Sts.,
Ottawa, Ont.

The City Department Indians Affairs

Dear Sir,

Not having received any word from Weyette regarding those drugs which we requisitioned for we would be very much obliged if you could kindly make inquiries for us a few instructions for them to be expressed to us as soon as possible or at the same time request them to send them certified spirit 95%

L.M. Dugas, Principal
April 22, 1944

To the Department of Indian Affairs

1/2 Gallon Rectified Spirit 95%

J.M. Dugas, Principal
Ottawa, 25th April 1914.

Rev. Sir,

Referring to letter to you of the 6th and your communication of the 22nd instant, I beg to say that Mr. J. P. Valiquette of this city is not in a position to supply the drugs which you require for the Spanish Industrial School and the order is being given to Mr. R. I. Harrison, druggist of this city.

If the drugs reach you in good order, you should certify the account and return to the Department in due course. I may say that the Department will not supply the rectified spirits asked for.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. L. V. Dugas, S.J.,
Principal,
Spanish River Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.
Sir,

I have to request that you will kindly supply the drugs mentioned on the list herewith enclosed for use at the Industrial Indian School at Spanish, Ont. The drugs should be pure and of the best quality and should be shipped by Dominion Express to the Rev. L.V. Duke, Principal, Spanish River Industrial School, Spanish, Ont. Kindly advise the principal of the date of shipment and send your account in triplicate to him, as his certificate thereto is required before payment can be considered by the Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Aest. Deputy and Secretary.

Mr. R.J. Harrison,
Musselst.,
Gov. Rideau & Cumberland Sta.,
Ottawa, Ont.

[Stamp]
Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Dear Sir,

I am writing to forward to you a small requisition for drugs. My superior tells me that you have been inquiring of the drugs I have received how they meet standards in quality.

I beg to state that so far I have no complaint to make in this regard but I would like to inform you that so far I cannot say that P.J. Harrison has shown the greatest solicitude in his service and therefore he my entire confidence in this account.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Thanking you most sincerely for your kindness.

Yours most sincerely,

H.M. [Signature]

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Ottawa, 15th June, 1914.

Rev. Sir:

I beg to say that Mr. T. Brownlee, druggist of this city, has been requested to supply you with the drugs for which you have made requisition on behalf of pupils of the Spanish Industrial School. When you receive the drugs, you should check them carefully, and if the order has been filled as per account which you will also receive, you should certify it and forward it to the Department with a view to payment.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. L.V. Dugas, S.J.,
Principal, Indian Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.
Ottawa, 15th June, 1914.

Sir:—

I enclose herewith a requisition for drugs required for use at the Indian Industrial School at Spanish, Ontario, and I have to request that you will kindly supply the same and ship them to the Principal of the Institution, whose address is, Rev. L.V. Dugas, Principal Indian Industrial School, Spanish, Ont. The drugs should be pure and of the best quality and securely packed. Your account should be sent in duplicate to the Principal of the School, and you should attach thereto the prepaid receipt for the express charges on the consignment.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Mr. T. Brownlee,
Druggist,
Corner Bank and Cooper Sts.,
Ottawa, Ont.

CANADA
Dear Sir,

The boxes came from Bretonville, but there is one box that came in very bad order so we return them to him to have some good ones instead.

The rest came in good order and will send you the certified bills as soon as we receive the Lithia tally.

Yours Truly,
L. W. Dugas
Principal
Spanish River Ind. School

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Ottawa, 14th August, 1914.

Rev. Sir:

With reference to your statement in letter of the 28th June that the drugs ordered from Mr. Brownlee, druggist of this city, for use at the Spanish River Industrial School were received, but that there was a shortage in connection therewith; I shall be glad to learn from you whether you have received the lithia tablets ordered. If they have reached you in good order, and if all the other articles for which you made requisition were received, you should certify the account and forward to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McFarlane,
Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. L.V. Dugan S.J.,
Principal, Indian Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Ottawa, 14th August, 1914.

Rev. Sir:-

In compliance with your request, the drugs for which you made requisition on the 6th instant for use on behalf of pupils of the Spanish River Industrial School have been ordered from the Carlton Drug Company. When you receive the drugs and the account for the same, you should carefully check over the account, certify, and forward it to the Department with a view to payment.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. L.V. Burgess S.J.,
Principal, Indian Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Ottawa, 14th August, 1914.

Sir:

I beg to transmit herewith a requisition for drugs required for use by the Rev. Principal of the Indian Industrial School at Spanish, Ont. The Department desires that you will kindly fill the order. The drugs should be pure and of the best quality, and should be securely packed. Your account in duplicate, and in detail, should be sent to the Principal, as his certificate thereto is required before the matter of payment can be dealt with by the Department. Kindly attach to the account the receipt for the prepaid express charged on this consignment.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary

The Carlton Drug Co.,
Wellington St.,
Ottawa, Ont.

Ottawa, 11th September, 1914.

Rev. Sir,

In compliance with your request, the drugs for which you made requisition on the 3rd instant for use on behalf of pupils of the Spanish River Industrial School have been ordered from the Carleton Drug Company. When you receive the drugs and the account for the same, you should carefully check over the account, certify, and forward it to the Department with a view to payment.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, 11th September, 1914.

Sir,

I beg to transmit herewith a list of drugs required for use at the Girls' Industrial School at Spanish, Ont. It is desired that you will kindly furnish the drugs in question and ship them by express to the Rev. L. V. Dugas, S.J., Industrial Indian School, Spanish, Ont. The drugs should be pure and of the best quality and should be securely packed. Your account in duplicate and in detail should be sent to the Principal, as his certificate thereunto is required before the matter of payment can be dealt with by the Department. Kindly attach to the account a receipt for the prepaid express charges on the consignment.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ass't Deputy and Secretary.

The Carleton Drug Company,
Wellington St.,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dec. 6, 1914.

Requisition for drugs

Alcock's Perine Plaster 2 lbs.

Prescription Scale
Hot Water Bags (25¢)

In the requisition of Sept. 8 asked for prescription scale and weight, received only the latter.

J. B. Bryan
Principal
Ottawa, 14th November, 1914.

Rev. Sir,

I beg to inform you that an order has been given to the Carleton Drug Company, of this city, for the supply of the articles mentioned on the list dated 5th November which you submitted to the Department. When you receive the drugs and the account for the same, you should carefully check over the account for the drugs, certify it and forward it to the Department for payment. The attention of the Carleton Drug Company has been drawn to your statement that you did not receive the scales for which you asked in requisition of the 3rd September though the weights were sent you.

Apparently you have not sent in a certified voucher for the drugs supplied you as per requisition of the 3rd September. You should forward it without delay.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. L. V. Dugas, S.J.,
Principal,
Spanish River Indian Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Ottawa, 14th November, 1914.

Sir,

I enclose herewith a list of drugs required for use at the Spanish River Industrial Indian School. The Department desires that you will kindly supply the same to the Principal, the Rev. L. V. Dugas, whose address is Spanish, Ont. The drugs should be pure and of the best quality and should be securely packed. Your account in detail and in duplicate should be sent to the Principal, as his certificate thereto is required before the matter of payment can be dealt with by the Department. Kindly attach to the account a receipt for the prepaid express charges on the consignment.

Your particular attention is drawn to the fact that the scales which were ordered from you on the 11th September (together with other articles for the Spanish Industrial School) were not received as pointed out by the Rev. Mr. Dugas in the requisition herewith transmitted. You will observe that he states he received the weights, but not the scales. He asked to be furnished with prescription scales and weights.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

The Carleton Drug Co.,
Wellington St.,
Ottawa, Ont.

Ottawa, 7th January, 1915.

Rev. Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 22nd ultimo, I beg to say that Mr. T. A. Brownlee, druggist, of this city, is being requested to ship to you by express the drugs for which you have made requisition for use at the Industrial School at Spanish. When you receive the consignment you should check over the list and if you find that the drugs are in order, you should certify Mr. Brownlee's account and forward it to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. L. V. Dugas, S.J.,
Principal,
Spanish River Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Ottawa, 7th January, 1915.

Sir,

I enclose herewith a list of drugs required for use at the Industrial Indian School at Spanish, Ont. The Department desires that you will kindly supply these goods which should be pure and of the best quality. They should be sent by express to the Rev. L. V. Dugas, Principal, of the above mentioned school, at Spanish. Kindly enclose with the drugs your account in duplicate for the articles supplied. You should attach to your account a receipt for the prepaid express charges on the consignment.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Mr. F. A. Brownlee,
Bank St.,
Ottawa, Ont.
Dear Sir,

You were kind enough to inform us that the requisition for drugs which we forwarded to you on or about December 23rd, 1914 had been placed with Bowles. As the goods have not arrived, would you have the kindness to give the druggist a reminder that they be sent without delay so they may be sent by Express mail.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Thanking you dear sir,
in anticipation thereof
I remain
yours sincerely
L. W. Osgood
Principal
Ottawa, Jan. 25, 1925.

Rev. Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 21st instant, in which you state that you have not received the drugs which were ordered for the Spanish School, from Mr. T. A. Brownlee of this city, I beg to say that Mr. Brownlee has been spoken to in the matter and he has promised to send the drugs to you at once by express. The delay was due to the fact that some articles for which you made request were not in stock.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. L. V. Dugas,
Principal, Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.

Rev. Sir:

The Department has received the requisition for drugs which you submitted recently for use on behalf of the girls of the Spanish River School; and in reply I beg to say that as the requisition is somewhat large, the Department desires to be informed how long you estimate that these drugs will last. I beg to point out that the total expenditure during the fiscal year 1914-15 for drugs for use at the Spanish River School amounted to $247.38. It is not considered advisable to buy in large quantities, as certain of the articles may deteriorate when kept on hand for any length of time. When your report in this matter is received, action will be taken.

I may say that the Department is considering the question of ordering the drugs required from a local druggist. Kindly state the names of druggists in the neighbouring towns who would be in a position to fill an order if given. The Department does not wish to deal with any firm which could not furnish fresh drugs of the best quality at reasonable rates. It is desired to curtail expenditure, compatible with the receipt of a satisfactory supply of drugs.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. L. V. Bugas,
Principal, Indian Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.

Dear Sir,

In answer to yours of April 8th No. 388664-1 re my requisition for girls school, I beg to say that our infirmary was sick and could not give me necessary information before today. Here is what he says: "The requisition will in all probability last well until the fall; it is far cheaper to buy drugs when possible in large quantity. In the order sent for the girls school I have well considered all questions of deterioration and by to say state that there is nothing of that nature in the order. I have over 25 years experience in medicine and surgery and you can rely on my attesting strict economy on this behalf as chief infirmary to these schools."

There is no drugstore in the neighboring towns who would be in a position to fill an order if given.

We buy all our drugs for our colleges from Lynam in Montreal, and find it OK.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Dear Sir,

I am writing to forward to you my fall-winter requisition. It may seem to you somewhat early or at the same time large, but I am sure you will agree. All my medical friends have been kind enough to warn me that before the end of September there will be quite an advance in prices on account of the war so that the prices will continue advancing up to the new year. Therefore, I deemed it prudent to try to economize by ordering early for fall-winter. I think it is highly imprudent that I shall require anything else before the new year.

Thanking you in anticipation,

I am,
Most respectfully yours in faith,

Fred. M. Stevenson, M.D.
Superintendent

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
NOTES ON SCHOOLS IN S. HAGAN'S AGENCY

I would suggest that a surprise inspection and examination of the school work at the convent be made, possibly by Mr. McGibbon, where he can test the efficiency of the system of tuition being given at the convent and the Department will then be in a position to determine just where the fault lies for the apathetic attitude of the Indians to school matters.
The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa

Indian Department, Winnipeg.
April 25th, 1916.

Sir,

This Requisition should have accompanied the one referring to the girls, which was sent several days ago in reply to letter from the Department.

It had not been properly attended to owing to my being connected with Military affairs, which took up so much of my time. I found out that I could not attend to both duties and be faithful to either, so I have resigned from my position with the Military Department, and I hope in future that you will not find any neglect on my part to your Department, as I intend to devote my time entirely to the Indian Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
To the Secretary
The Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

481153

Dear Sir,

On the 15th of March I had the honour to forward to you a requisition for drugs. On the (38664-1) 1st of April you informed me that Mr. Beatty of Ottawa had received orders from you to supply us with the said requisites.

It is now the 26th of April and there is no sign of invoice or drugs from the said Mr. Beatty.

I therefore respectfully beg to call your attention to the matter as I am becoming embarrassed over this long delay, and I sincerely hope you will be able to find means of rounding up the request in prompt attention.

I would respectfully beg to remark that the only firms who have given us absolute satisfaction in any respect as regards promptness in shipment, perfection in quality of the drugs, & the packing of the same, is the firm of Messrs. Lyman Ltd., Montreal.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
May 12th 1916

481675

Sir,

I beg to inform the Dept. that we had to close the classes last Monday on account of the measles. Many of the children were sick with it but no one dangerously, we hope to be able to open the classes by very long now.

Yours truly,

L.M. Dumas,
Principal.
Ottawa, May 15, 1916.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th instant informing the Department that you have had to close the classes in the Spanish River Industrial School on account of measles.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is glad to learn that none of the children are dangerously ill with this disease and it is hoped that you will soon be able to re-open the classes again.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. L. N. Riggs, S.J.,
Principal,
Spanish River Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.

Ottawa, October 6th., 1916.

Rev. Sir,

The Department received on the 4th instant the requisition for drugs which you made on behalf of the Girls' Industrial School at Spanish; and in reply I regret to say that the said requisition will not be filled, as in July last, the Department authorized the supply of drugs for this school, while on the 13th September drugs were ordered for the Boys' School at Spanish. It is considered therefore that you have already received a sufficient supply of drugs for use during the fall and winter, and if further drugs are required, they should be paid for by the school.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. L. N. Pugmire, S.J.,
Principal,

Spanish, Ont.

Oct. 12th 1916

Dear Sir,

Re your ref. No. 388664/1A dated Oct. 6th 1916 I beg to remind the Dept. that we had an epidemic of measles last spring when about 10 children were sick at the same time, and that brought the drug supply to an end, so you must not think that we ask more than what is necessary, we have no drug store around here and in a case of sickness we need to have the drugs on hand. I send you a new requisition for the girls dept. which they make as small as possible and hope that the Department will grant them the drugs needed.

With the little revenue of the school we cannot provide the children with more than food and clothes especially now that the prices are so high on everything.

Looking forward to receiving a favorable answer.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]

L. M. Rogers
Principal

Dear Sir,

I forget to ask you a favor—

Will you kindly see Mr. Lawrence, our great old friend and advocate, here to obtain for us £125.00 instead of £100.00 as per capita grant for our children.

We are going under every year and at the price of things are very near being able to keep up our good work—your influence is great in Ottawa and you may believe.

S. Palmer
Dear Mr. Scott,

You have probably wondered at my not writing to you since January. The reason is that my new quiet mode of life in this school has brought on me so much constant headache that I was often unable to do even my official correspondence. I have now come to beg your benevolent advice on a very important question for us.

The discouragingly high cost of living, and the lack of outside resources, have made it extremely hard, not to say impossible for us, to continue the sustenance of the material management of the two sections of our school. We have many Brothers and Sisters very anxious to continue to devote their lives to the great work of which you have the general direction; but material means are wanting. Would your Department
be disposed to buy our two schools and their farms, and employ us at the intellectual and spiritual management of them; as you are doing for these Western Industrial schools, owned by the Oblate Fathers?

A word of answer would greatly oblige.

Your very humble and grateful servant,

Eug. A. Papineau, O.F.M.
Principal
August 30, 1917.

My dear Father Papineau,

I was very sorry to learn from your letter of the 18th instant that you are not in good health and have been suffering from headaches. When one considers the many details that you have to attend to and the worries of such a large institution, one sympathizes with you very heartily. I hope now that you may be feeling better. As you are no doubt aware, we have increased the per capita grant for the Spanish River school by $10.00 for the current fiscal year, and this is the best we can do. It would be impossible for us to finance the purchase of your properties, even if the Government were to consider your suggestion favourably. We are not undertaking any new building operations or the acquisition of any new establishments. You might at some convenient time, however, let me know at what amount you value the properties.

With kind regards, I am

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Rev. Eug. A. Papineau, S.J.,
Principal,
Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.

Dear Mr. Benson,

I am writing to ask you to favour me by making some inquiries for me and let me know the result. And I will proceed to explain.

In my experience as the information of this establishment for the past 6 years, it has been necessary to do a considerable amount of extraction of teeth owing to not having the necessary tools fit for filling teeth (which branch of mine have considerable experience). It has been my observation to have to extract many teeth all which could have stood many years had only had the necessary instruments etc. to have saved them by filling.

So I would ask you to kindly make inquiries to whether the Department could supply me with a metal outfit for the purpose of saving many of the teeth as possible as I find that fills keep when less traumatic teeth are hampered by considerably on account of malnutrition.

Can I rely on your satisfaction and will you fall in with my request for medicines?

Thanking you in anticipation.

Yours sincerely in Jesus Christ,

[Signature]

Dear Very Kind Mr Scott,

I desire accept my sincere gratitude for your sympathetic letter of Aug 20.

I must also offer you many warm thanks for the increase of the grant. I know that we all owe this entirely to your proverbial devotedness to our Schools.

Without financing now the purchase of our properties, would the Department be willing to buy them now and pay the capital after a convenient number of years? You would just pay the interest (say 6%) of the total purchase.

The Boy's school property, i.e., School, saw mill and planing mill; barns and dependencies,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
with six hundred acres of land have cost us sixty thousand dollars.

The Girls' School properties: School; Laundry; barns and nearly 400 acres of land, have cost them ninety thousand dollars.

It would make a total purchase of one hundred and fifty thousand dollars.

Hoping that you will see your interest and advantage in the transaction,

Yours very respectfully and devotedly,

Eug. A. Papineau, s.j.

Dear Mr. Benson,

I regret to have to inform you that I have been sent to the infirmary with a case of blood poisoning in the left wrist.

On Thursday last (14.2.18) I had the doctor from Ottawa under chloroform there were some incisions practised to drain out the pus.

I fear that it is going to be a considerable time before there will be much improvement. There is still danger for him losing the hand, whereas if a complete dissection of the part were practised which would necessitate him going to hospital I have very reason to believe the hand will be saved.

A word from you by telegraph & I will take him to either Sudbury or North Bay or in fact any hospital you will designate or I will keep him here what ever you wish.

Yours sincerely in Jesus Christ

[Signature]

CANADA
Dear Sir:

Children have entered our school this year in larger number than any previous year. We have already 96 boys, 96 girls; a few more are to come soon, and I have requested girls to number for want of room and not to exceed the number of 208 for both institutions.

Comes the question if we should profit our school to accommodate a larger number of children or not. We are ready to do it if the Department of Indian Affairs would guarantee the ordinary grant for a number of children not exceeding 250, boys and girls. The girls school is large enough for all its parts for 125 children. The dormitory can contain only 100 beds, but this can be enlarged by adding half of the third story of the loft building. All other parts of the house are large enough for 125 children.

It is my opinion that the boarding school will be more and more the means of educating the Indians of this part of the Country. The day schools have not reached great many Indian children. The proportion of those who attend these day schools seems rather to decrease, and the some of the many reasons are the following: The Indians are not...
As before grouped in villages, they rather tend to disperse all over their respective preserves for farming purposes. The high wages in saw mills and lumber camps, the berry picking, sugar making keeps always many families shifting about. For these reasons, some schools around here have to close periodically, so Serpent River School, Spanish River (Magamook), South Bay, Whitefish Lake.

The new location of our boarding school has afforded school facilities to many band of Indians who had never previously sent children to Rekemukay. We now receive children from adjoining, other bands, from Abitibi, Mohawk and we have application from Lake Superior Indians. I have already refused quite a number of children and some are orphans or destitute children.

If the Indian Department allows us to increase the number of our boarders, we will prepare to answer all the Applications.

Very sincerely Yours,

Mr. Martin Benson
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

T. A. Desautels, J.P.

October 14th 1918

I am in receipt of yours of the 12th inst. concerning the increase of grant-earning pupils in our school. The answer was in the negative for the reason that the appropriation for school purposes is limited.

Then I would beg the Department to consider another proposition. Our school has now the full number of children allowed: 100 boys. There is no margin left for urgent cases that present themselves among them. Lately I had to refuse five very poor and orphan boys for the reason that the number of children allowed in our school was filled. Parents will bring us from far distance children without previous notice. It is not easy to turn them away.

There are here some 7 or 8 boys undesirable, just lazy, disobedient, exercising bad influence on others. One of them is dangerous, one has sore eyes. I would propose the discharge of these boys so they draw very little advantage by being here and they fill the place of others. If this is granted, which I desire much, I would propose names and add explanation. I would be pleased to receive your cheque at the quarter ending Sept 30th. We are in need of them.

The Sec. of the Dept. of Ind. Affairs. Sincerely yours,

T.A. Beaule, J.

Sir,

I have been instructed by phone from S. Hagan, Indian Agent, Thessalon, to notify you that he is quarantined at his daughter's house and not able to communicate with the Department as his office is not near this house.

He wished me to say that he is in good health, also to let you know that up to last night there has been 20 Indians died at Spanish Mills of Flu, these were from several different bands, also that 7 girls and 3 boys have died at the Spanish Industrial School of this disease.

Yours obediently,

Edward Beesaw,
Constable.

Box 83.
Ottawa, November 12, 1918.

Rev. Sir,

The Department is advised that seven girls and three boys have died at the Spanish River Industrial School from the Spanish Influenza.

I have to ask you to be good enough to furnish the Department with a full report in regard to the epidemic of this disease at your school.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. T. A. Desautels, B.J.,
Principal,
Spanish River Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.
I'm afraid you have been informed of the great tidal wave which has swept over these last weeks. The Spanish influenza has visited us in all its severity. It broke out first at the girls' school, the 21st Oct., and in three days all the girls except three and some members of the staff were ill. Three days after it started in the boys' school, and in a few days, all the boys except three and six members of the staff were sick. We had many serious cases, lungs, kidneys, and ears troubles; many cases of pneumonia. I regret to state that we had to register some losses in both schools; the following is the death record:

Oct. 28th No. 0402 Clara O'Banion, 17 years, 4th Standard, Manitoulin unseeded.

Oct. 29th No. 0447 Ellen Manitoulin, 8 years, 3rd Std. Cockburn Island.

Oct. 31st No. 0452 Ernestine Cochereau, 7 years, 1st Std. West Bay; Oct. 31st No. 0275 Mathilda Rizzalino, 16 years, 5th Std. Thessalon.

Nov. 1st No. 0387 Rose Demignano, 10 years, 4th Std. Manitoulin unseeded; Nov. 3rd No. 0395 Mary Medweissch, 12 years, 3rd Std. Manitoulin unseeded.

Nov. 3rd No. 0288 Annie Beaucousong, 14 years, 5th Std. Manitoulin unseeded; Nov. 12th No. 0448 Virginia Cochereau, 2 years, 1st Std. West Bay.

Babies: — Nov. 4th No. 677 Anges Fairbell, Wyche, 2nd Std. Cahoonawaga; Nov. 4th No. 552 Moise Minibeshkana, 7 years, 1st Standard Spanish River; Nov. 5th No. 533 Michel Akironge, 7 years, 1st Std. Casa Cocker.

No. 7 No. 543 Edmond Wiskamagad, 11 years, 3rd Std.
Marie Leduc, aged 12 years, No. 539, Jerome Kitchik, 18 years, No. 546, Joseph Cameron, 11 years, No. 547, Joseph Cameron, 11 years, No. 548, Alexander Wenzig, 13 years, No. 549, Manitoba, No. 550, No. 551, Joseph Broussard, 15 years, Industrial Course, Shoemaker at Regis. In all 8 girls and 8 boys.

We have still a few in bed recovering slowly. Some of the most serious cases who have partly recovered might remain so weak that they would not be able to attend their school duties, and some might develop tubercular diseases. I will report on such cases of experience prove they turn that way.

Thanks to the Indian Department, we have been well supplied with drugs. We tried to give the children the best medical and nursing attendance we could in these circumstances. We had the help of one physician from the hospital and of two from Montreal.

I do not believe a letter from Mr. Agent of the Indian Affairs, in which he quoted the following statement from Mr. J. Stuart of the Board of Health, "Replying to your letter of the 20th reporting outbreak by tuberculosis at the Industrial School at Pointe-au-Pic, the Department approves Dr. McDermott's engagement to attend these cases, and you should see that every attention is paid to nourishing and medical attendance to your patients." I concluded from this that Mr. Dr. McDermott was at the charge of the sick. In addition, he has regular visits to the sick at our schools, mostly every day. He has shown ability and devotionness in the fulfillment of his duties.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
We have been doing more than ordinary infirmary work; we had real hospital work and we had to undergo some extra expenses. I appeal to the kindness of the Department to help us to solve our expenses at least the bill of the extra infirmaries which will amount to $150.00.

We hope to start teaching in a few days after the washing and disinfection of the buildings is finished.

You will find enclosed the Admission Papers of Ernestine Cobine and Basil Micah Mingina. They entered on the date marked on their papers.

Three boys who have completed their course of study last summer, asked to stay a few months more in the school to learn some trade in their respective trade. Isaiah Beausrais was a shoemaker.

Joseph Martin applied himself to carpentry and cabinet work. Auguste Beausrais applied himself to farm work especially to ploughing. They wish now to be discharged, and I beg for their discharge by the Almighty in their best interests.

No. 419 Joseph Martin 16 years, St Regis, entered Sept 28, 1913

No. 387 Auguste Beausrais, 15 years, Laughlinaga, entered October 3, 1912.

Hereunder is the certificate of health of Peter Johnson. Owing to his predisposition, this boy was badly dying of the influenza, he will be able to attend his regular school duties this year. I should advise to discharge him too.

No. 416 Peter Johnson 16 years, St Regis.

I suppose these boys are entitled to their fair pay by the Department.

Very sincerely yours,

T. A. Desjardins, A. I.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Ottawa, November 23, 1913.

Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant in which you inform the Department of the death of eight boys and eight girls at the Spanish River Industrial School as a result of the severe epidemic of Spanish influenza.

The death of these pupils is very much regretted. The Department is satisfied that every care and attention was given them by yourself and members of your staff as well as Dr. McDermott. It is hoped that the pupils are now all on a fair way to recovery and that no further deaths will occur. The class work should be resumed again as soon as the disinfection and cleaning is completed.

The expenses incurred by you in the employment of the extra infirmarians to the amount of $150.00 will be paid and you should forward vouchers, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure to the above amount.

With reference to the request for the discharge of pupils Nos. 419, Joseph Martin and 367, Angus Ignatius Beuvaisi, I beg to say that enquiries are being made from the agents at St. Regis and Caughnawaga as to what disposition is to be made of these boys when they arrive home. As soon as a reply is received you will be given further instructions. The cost of their transport will be paid by the Department.

With reference to pupil No. 416, Peter Johnson, I have to acknowledge the receipt of a certificate from Dr. McDermott regarding the health of this boy and recommending that he be discharged from the school. As the parents of this boy are dead, enquiry is being made as to what arrangements can be made for his care if it is decided to return him to St. Regis. I have to request that you will be good enough to have Dr. McDermott furnish a report as to whether he considers this boy would be likely to benefit if he were sent to a sanatorium. If there is a reasonable hope that he will recover his health arrangements might be made to have him placed in a sanatorium. However, before any action is taken Dr. McDermott should give a report and also state whether he considers that it would be advisable to have him sent to a sanatorium.

I have also to acknowledge the receipt of applications and certificates of health for the admission of Ernestine Corbiere and Basil Nishibinjima, and in reply I beg to say that the admission of these two children is approved. The application of Ernestine Corbiere is returned herewith as the signature of the witness has not been filled in and this should be done and the application returned to the Department. In future, the Department would like you to forward all applications for admission to the agent of the band to which the children belong for his approval before the applications are sent in to the Department.

Your obedient servant

Rev. T. A. Desmulets, S.J.,
Principal,
Indian Industrial School
Spanish, Ont.

J. D. McLEAN
Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Dear Sir:

CANADA
Dear Sir,

Perhaps you will find my report a little lengthy, specially the item about the buildings. So, if you find useless passages in this chapter, I shall not be offended if you cut out them. The same about the correction of language as I have not the pretension to be a scholar in English language.

As you will notice, the boys have been granted a typewriter, and the girls have none, and they are anxious to have it also. The teacher of the girls' senior class, Miss Jenkins, told me many times she would be delighted to teach her typewriting to the girls. I think it would be a step more towards progress and an advantage for the girls if they learn typewriting, thus they would run a chance of getting a better position than housemaids, etc., they would associate with a higher class of people than they do in hotels where so many Indian girls are inclined to engage them. If the Department, after kindly considering this matter, decides to grant this favour, it would be greatly appreciated.

Sincerely Yours,

T.A. Desautels

Ottawa, May 16th, 1919.

Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, in which you tender your resignation as Principal of the Spanish River Industrial school.

During the time you have been in charge of this school, continued progress has been evident and this was, no doubt, due to your interest and zeal in the welfare of the Indians.

The Department accepts your resignation with regret and extends its best wishes for your success in your new field of labour.

The appointment of Rev. V. Gravel, S.J., as your successor, is approved.

Your obedient servant

J. D. McLean

Faire un bain de savon tiède (30 à 40 degrés) en y ajoutant un peu d'ammoniaque, y laisser tremper la bande une heure environ.
Nettoyer en pressant le tissu et rincer avec soin à l'eau pure. Ramasser la bande sur elle-même et la bien serrer dans la main pour permettre au crêpage de se reformer.
Laisser sécher dans cet état, sans allonger, c'est-à-dire ne pas suspendre comme on fait d'ordinaire pour la linge. — Ne jamais repasser. — En procédant ainsi les bandes retrouveront leur élasticité.

Seuls Agents pour le Canada:
Rougier frères, Montreal.

Hospital Crêpe bandage: INVICTA
a rubberless elastic material
The only one which will not ravel
RED LINE QUALITY
five widths: 2, 3, 4, 8 and 12 inches

Directions for cleansing.
Soak the bandage for about one hour in lukewarm water with a little ammonia. To cleanse, press the textile and rinse thoroughly with fresh water. Gather up the bandage with one hand, press firmly so as to form the Crepe again. Let dry in this state, without stretching, that is to say, do not hang up like other clothes. Do not iron. In following the above, the bandage will keep its elasticity.

Sole Agents for Canada:
Rougier frères, Montreal.

Dear Sirs:

I wish to report to you that I have under my care 50 cases of Influenza among the children at the School. I doubt this may spread to the 200 children at the School. I have them at present under Board of Health Vaccination treatment.

Sincerely Yours,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Ottawa, October 2, 1919.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo reporting an outbreak of twenty cases of whooping cough at the Spanish River Industrial School.

In reply I beg to say that it is regretted that this outbreak has occurred.

It is noted that you have the children under Board of Health Vaccine treatment, and it is hoped that yourself, aided by the staff of the school will be able to prevent the spread of this disease among the other pupils. You should see that the pupils affected receive the necessary treatment.

Your obedient servant,

H. D. McLEAN
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. J. Hodnett, Esq., M.D.,
Massay,
Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
March 11th/23

The Dept. of Admin Affairs
Ottawa Ont.

Dear Sir:

Louis LeGros, a pupil of the
Industrial School at Spanish, Ont., requires
urgent attention in a hospital. I advise
that she be removed to Sudbury
Hospital at once for operation.

Sincerely yours,

J. L. [Signature]
M. O.
Trinity Ont.
March 12th 1920

Dear Sir,

Please find enclosed a letter from Doctor McPheron, advising me to send Louise MacGowan, pupil, No. 464, to the hospital.

We have been trying for several days to reach her mother who passed the winter at Little Current, Ont., but we could not trace her there. We have also tried at Naukwa Creek and Segwun, where a sister of Louise was living, and also without success. Should the doctor of the hospital say that an operation is necessary away we will try to proceed with it, without the mother's consent! The mother has always looked after the child; she has separated, I think, from her husband. We cannot find the whereabouts within.

Will the Dept. pay for the expenses incurred?

Your obedient servant,

V. Grant, S./
Principal

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

P.S. The doctor thinks that the child is suffering from an abscess in the skin.

Dear Sir:

A pupil of the Industrial School at Spanish, Delia Doan, is ill with Diphtheria and Pneumonia with slight amount of effusion. I advise her removal to Sudbury Hospital for surgical treatment.

Sincerely Yours,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Please find enclosed a Doctor Certificate in favour of Delia Dohm, hospital No. 671. The mother is at home at Govt. Bay. I sent a telegram to Mr. Haddon, Sheriff, asking him to let her come if she was permitted. She answered saying that she could not do so. Fortunately Miss Dohm (or John Clark) arrived and when the Doctor advised me to remove the child to the hospital, he sent a telegram to Mr. Agent Lewis; but fearing the answer would not come in time, he asked me to take her to hospital as he could not go himself. She left yesterday.

Miss Dohm went with her; she is expected to be accompanied on our return by Misses McLean who has sufficiently recovered to be dismissed from the Hospital.

Your obedient servant,

V. Grant, S.F.
Principal
Industrial School
Spanish, Ont.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, April 19, 1920.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 17th instant enclosing a doctor's certificate regarding the serious illness of Delia Dokum, pupil No. 0511 of the Spanish River Industrial School, whom you have sent to the hospital in Sudbury on the doctor's advice.

In reply I beg to say that your action in this matter is approved. The Department will pay reasonable charges for her as a patient in the public ward during the time she is in the hospital.

It is noted that Louise McGraw, whom you were authorized by telegram of the 16th of March last, to send to the hospital, has sufficiently recovered to be dismissed from the hospital.

Accounts, in duplicate, covering the hospital charges for these pupils should be forwarded to the Department for payment as soon as both receive their discharge.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. V. Garvel, S.J.,
Principal,
Spanish River Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Gore Bay, Ontario, June 11th, 1920.

Dear Sir,

I have a request from the Spanish River Industrial School for the purchase of sprinkling pails to be used in watering their School Gardens. These sprinklers would probably be a better method of applying the water than from the ordinary pails and I recommend that they be allowed to purchase one half dozen sprinkling pails for each of the two schools or one dozen in all.

Very truly yours,

[Signature]
Agricultural Representative.

Mr. J. D. McLean,
Sec'y Indian Department,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, June 15, 1920.

Reverend Sir,

Mr. Metcalf, Agricultural Representative, requests that authority be granted for the purchase of twelve sprinkling pails to be used in the watering of the school gardens at the Spanish Industrial School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the purchase of these pails. You should obtain prices from a number of dealers carrying these articles and purchase the twelve sprinkling pails from the firm quoting you the lowest price. This is in accordance with the requirements of the War Purchasing Commission.

You will be good enough to furnish properly receipted vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of these pails together with a list of the dealers from whom you obtain prices and the prices quoted by them. As soon as these are received payment of the account will be made.

Your obedient servant,

M. D. McLean

Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Rev. W. Gravel, S.J.,
Principal,
Indian Industrial School
Spanish, Ont.

Rev. Sir,

In your requisition for drugs you ask for 2 oz. Codeine Sulphate which costs $11.55 an ounce, and as the quantity asked for is considered altogether too much, it will not be supplied until an explanation is received from you as to the necessity for such a large quantity.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

Some of Sept. 12, 1920, to hand.

Regarding the Codine Syrup (20g) suggested each ounce syrup when combined with Spasac & ammonia between one or one half (1/2) or two (2) gals of the most effective cough syrup on the market. I have consulted several doctors & shown to them my prescription of cough syrup & they are all agreed that for a place like this where on account of general tendency to coughing most of the boys being thrown or have delicate conditions as regards their respiratory organs, it is naturally necessary to be very circumspect as to what remedies are to be used for the purpose of stopping & relieving their coughing which usually begins in November about the time of October & continues more or less till April. I usually dispense from 5 to 7 gals of syrup in a year but this I am able to procure Codine Syrup & is a matter of from 3½ to 5 gals. You are advised to send me one ounce (1oz) now & I will negotiate more than I have used the (1oz) it will be cheaper to you than 5 to 7 gals of cough syrup which is far superior to any own prescription & does not cause any disturbance of the stomach & whether the common faults of most of the cough syrups on the market. In regard to the 15 gals of Codine Syrup we have 10 boys who have the habit of

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
In accordance with your instructions I visited the Spanish River Industrial School, while on my recent trip in that section.

The principal of the school was absent at the time of my visit, having gone to Little Current on business in connection with the school. His assistant showed me through the various buildings and did everything possible to give me an insight into their work and method of handling their pupils.

In visiting the boys' dormitory I found that the beds were well provided with bedding and although it was in the latter part of the week when I made my visit, the bed clothing was clean. Considerable difficulty was found in keeping some of the beds in proper condition on account of bedewing by some of the smaller boys. Rubber sheets are used on these beds but the quality of rubber sheeting was very poor and thin. The greater part of the beds were not made up at the time I saw them, about ten A.M. The Asst. Principal explained that this was on account of the necessity of airing the beds.

The boys are provided with plain but warm clothing and have a change of underwear every week. They sleep in their underwear. All the boys get a bath once a week and their heads are kept close cropped.

Their food consists of, for breakfast porridge, milk, bread and butter; dinner, meat, potatoes, bread; on Fridays they have macaroni instead of meat; for supper beans or corn porridge, bread and butter. But they get only once a day. The bread is a sort of black bread made from a formula obtained from some medical man who is known to them. It is objected to by the pupils, some of whom say that they cannot eat it at all.

The boys take turns at the outside work. Seven or eight are required for milking. Four work at shoe making and repairing. Three work at carpentering. In summer some work in the garden and some five on the farm. The work is done during one hour after breakfast and one hour before supper. I do not think that any are overworked. The older boys help with the thrashing.

The school location does not appear to me to be a good one from a health standpoint. It is low and boggy. Land that has been cleared for some time is still very boggy. In the mornings there is always a mist hanging over the place. It seems to me to be about the worst possible location for any person who is at all subject to tubercular troubles of any kind.
I found the girl's school to be in much better condition than the boys'. The building is a better one and is kept much cleaner. The location, however, has the same fault as that of the other school, both being built on the low land down near the lake.

I noticed, when passing the cemetery that there appeared to be quite a number of graves. By looking over the fence I could count over 60 graves and there were probably some others which I could not see on account of the tall grass. That seems to be a great many for such a short time as the school has been in existence.

I saw the Simon boys and they appeared to be in good health and not suffering from being underfed. I asked them if they wanted to leave the school and they said not. They may have been influenced by the presence of the teacher at the time.

From what I saw, while at the school, I would consider that the unfortunate location was the greatest fault. It seems to me that there is bound to be sickness on this account. The food provided, while plain enough, of great variety, is not stinted in quantity. The only complaint in regard to quality might be in the matter of the bread. The clothing provided is sufficient and cleanliness of body is well looked after.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector.

A. F. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Yours very truly,

January 3rd, 1921.

Rev. and dear Sir,

As you are aware, the Department received some complaints as to the quality of the bread that was being furnished the pupils of the Spanish River Industrial school, and Mr. Phelan was requested, when he visited the institution, to bring home with him a sample loaf which you were kind enough to give to him.

The loaf was submitted to the Chief Government Analyst, of the Department of Trade and Commerce, and I think I cannot do better than to enclose herewith a copy of the report received.

One of the claims made to the Department was that the bread was very often sour. You will notice that the report of the Analyst shows that, while the nutritive value of the sample sent in is about the average, there was evidence of sourness.

As bread is one of the staple articles of diet in all institutions of this kind the greatest care should be taken to see that only that of the best quality is furnished the children. I am sure that you will exercise the necessary care to see that the wishes of the Department in this respect are carried out.

Yours very truly,

Rev. V. Gravel, S.J.,
Principal,
Spanish Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Dear Mr. [Name],

I acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th instant; and in answer I beg to say:

1. That we use no second grade flour in our bread nor any substitute other than

2. Two and a half or three bags of brown or whole wheat flour.

3. That this small quantity of brown or whole wheat flour was added to the flour at the request of our Doctor. Many children who are not used to eat bread at home, suffer from constipation when they are here; and to do away with this, which after a while becomes suffocating, Dr. MacDermott told me that we should return to the brown bread.

If the Doctor thinks that we should give the children pure white bread only, I am ready to give it to them; it was not a question of economy that prompted me to give them brown bread; but a question of health. Practically there is no economy as children eat more of the brown than of the pure white bread. I can say that I have never heard a boy or a girl complain about it either. They prefer the brown to the white. I can also say that to my knowledge we never gave our bread to the children.

Now may I ask the Chief Government Analyst when the analysis of this loaf of bread was begun? We never give to the children, nor to the staff, any brown bread more than three or four days old; because we know that, on account of the bran especially, this bread becomes sour in a short time.

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
The sample given to Mr. Phelan had been baked exactly 40 hours before it left the house. Therefore I would be glad to know when the analysis was started in order to explain why it was found slightly sour.

Your letter makes me think that there are other complaints as you say that "one of the claims made to the Dept. was that the tree was very often sour."

I would be most grateful to you if you would kindly let me know of these other claims.

Your obedient servant,
V. Grant, S.S. Principal
Industrial School,
Sarnia, Ont.

Mr. Duncan C Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I was at Guelph the early part of this week, taking over some supplies from the Soldiers' Civil Re-establishment. Among other things I obtained a number of manual training sets consisting of the bench and necessary tools. Four of these sets I ordered to be shipped to you, freight charges collect. There will be no charge for the goods themselves. I am sure that you will find these of great value in your work with the boys of your institution. We are taking over some other supplies, which will be distributed at a later date. Will you kindly advise the Department when this shipment arrives.

Yours very truly,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
March 15th 1921

Dear Sir,

Dr. Mc Dermott was here yesterday to examine a few children who suffer from a slight attack of grip. He found one, little Louis Dubois, patient No. 573, who should be sent to the hospital. It is a case of pneumonia.

Dr. Mc Dermott found pain in the lower part of his right lung and advised me to send a word to the mother of the child to have permission to treat him in the hospital. It may take a long while before I can reach the mother. May I send the boy to bed now and have him treated there at Saint Joseph Hospital?

Your obedient servant,

V. Grant, Principal
Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Ottawa, March 17, 1921.

Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, in which you state that Dr. McDermott recommends that Louis Debeau, pupil No. 793, be sent to the hospital at Sudbury.

In reply I beg to say that you may send this boy to the hospital at that point. The Department will pay reasonable charges for him as a patient in the public ward during the time he is in the hospital.

It is noted that you are endeavouring to locate his mother in order to advise her regarding her son's condition.

Accounts, in duplicate, covering the hospital charges for this pupil should be certified by you and forwarded to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant

J. D. McLean
Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Rev. V. Gravel, S.J.,
Principal,
Indian Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I wish to advise you that there has been considerable sickness at the Industrial Schools. Spanish during the month of March and against General Topic. Saturday we had 48 cases of influenza besides several cases of pleurisy and pneumonia. They all seem to be doing well.

Ottawa, March 31, 1921.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 28th instant enclosing a report from Dr. McDermott regarding the condition of health of the pupils of the Spanish Industrial School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is communicating with the Principal regarding the cases of influenza reported by the doctor.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Samuel Hagen, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Thessalon, Ont.
Dear Sir,

I acknowledge the receipt of your letter of March 31st in 388664 re influenza.

In answer I am very glad to say that there are only two children still ill and today, one boy and one girl, and both are expected to be up in a few days.

During the month of March there were 62 cases treated in the infirmary. Fortunately the attack of influenza was not severe; much coughing, but little fever. After three or four days they were better. None relapsed. Those who had a beginning of pleurisy, &c., of pneumonia, &c., are now out with the others, but kept under special care and diet.

Classes were interrupted three days in all.

After the mild winter we had and following sudden change, the temperature it was expected that some kind of disease would visit us. It came quite suddenly just the same, but thank God, it was not severe.

Doctor Macdonald hopes that it will not be necessary to send Joseph to Dr. Lewis Delean to be bury for his operation. This boy is in great pain now and is doing very much better. I keep his mother well informed.

Your obedient servant,

V. Grant

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6217, file 471-1, part 1)
Ottawa, March 31, 1921.

Rev. Sir,

The Department has received the report of Dr. McDermott for the month of March on the condition of health of the pupils of the Spanish Industrial School. The doctor reports that there were 45 cases of influenza, besides several cases of pleurisy and pneumonia, and that all these cases seem to be doing well.

I will be pleased to have a report from you as to the progress being made towards the recovery of all the children who are sick. It is hoped that there will be no deaths and that the pupils will fully recover and that no further cases will develop.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. J. Gravel, S.J.,
Principal,
Spanish Industrial School,
Spanish, Ont.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

**PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA**
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the [School Name] School for the Quarter ended March 31, 1943.

Principal: [Signature]

Dated: April 1, 1943

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the [Name of School] Residential School for the Quarter ended [Date].

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.
