CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Indian Residential School (B) School for the Quarter ended Sept. 30, 1950.

Principal [Signature]

Dated Sept. 30, 1950

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

[Signature]

Indian Agent

Dated at Appin, Ontario this 30th September, 1950.

NOTE

Principals will please be guided by the instructions printed on the last page.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the [School Name] School for the Quarter ended Dec 31, 1950.

[Signature]

this 31st Dec., 1950

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in which all pupils were present (irrespective of whether they attended or not), adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Indian Residential School Boys School for the Quarter ended Dec. 31st 1950.

Principal. (Signature)

Dated Dec. 31st 1950

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

(Signature)

Indian Agent

Indian Residential School
Spanish Ontario
Jan 19th 1948

Dear Mr Neary;

With reference to yours of December 30th 1947... re science equipment... I have had one of our teachers make out a list of the prices from Central Scientific Company 129 Adelaide St.W Toronto... the reagents are not catalogued. She suggests $10.00 as an approximate price...

Yours sincerely,

(Rev) J.R. Oliver S.J.
Principal

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare and Training
Indian Affairs Branch Ottawa...
Dear Father Oliver:

With reference to your letter of January 19th enclosing a list of the science equipment which is required at the Spanish Indian Residential School, you may arrange for the purchase of this equipment from the Central Scientific Company, 129 Adelaide St. W., Toronto, Ont., at an approximate cost of $66.52. A copy of the list which you forwarded is returned herewith.

An itemized account, in duplicate, should be forwarded to the Department for payment.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Rev. J. R. Oliver, S.J.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Spanish, Ont.

We have ordered in this way one book per pupil and one
for the teacher.Our Physics set up is going to be
an expensive outlay from our ordinary budget.is there
any chance of getting a grant to cover it.Even on a mod-
est scale the setting up of a lab. for High School
Physics is very expensive.Would like to know what help
we can get.

Sorry to be so late requisitioning Grade XI books but
had to be sure the boys were coming back and waited for
word from them...

Indian Affairs Ottawa.

Indian Residential School
Spanish Ontario
August 6th 1948

Dear Mr Neary;
Since all of our grade ten boys are coming back to the school here for grade eleven, we must requisition books for that grade. Under Mr Bulger's guidance we are arranging our program for grades nine and ten in such wise that they will be combined for social studies science and English. This offers no difficulty since the Social Studies for ten does not in any way "depend" on the course done in nine. Likewise for the Science I and II, and so for the play prose and comp taken in the two grades. There are some subjects in which the ten pre-supposes a background from nine, these will be taught as formerly separately. As a result of this plan which will permit of more thoroughness (and for that reason was advocated by Inspector Bulger) we need the following to have all our nine and ten texts set for the year. I am taking it for granted that all the nines are continuing and that the pupils who passed entrance will be back plus two more for high school, one St Regis and one Shishigewaning.

Number required
Grades nine and ten...
Geography for Today Book II Longmans Green... 15...
History of Canadian People Wallace Copp Clarke... requisitioned but not received..................32
Parlez Vous Francais Copp Clark.............6
Latin for Secondary Schools....................25

.................................cont'd......2
August 11, 1948.

Dear Father Oliver:

I have your requisition of August 6th requesting a quantity of Text books for High School pupils.

Please be advised that it will be in order to purchase the necessary books locally in order to have them on hand when the school opens in September. The account should be forwarded to this office, quoting this letter as authority.

With reference to the Physics Laboratory, you will be hearing from us later.

Sincerely yours,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Rev. J.R. Oliver, S.J.,
Principal,
Spanish Residential School,
Spanish, Ontario.

NFT/HM.

Dear Sir,

The Auditor, Mr. K. A. Cameron has just made a very helpful suggestion to me for the better keeping of accounts. This requires two books. Mr. Cameron, who is here now, advised me to request you to send me at your earliest convenience

December 15, 1948.

Rev. J.R. Oliver, S.J.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Spanish, Ontario.

Dear Father Oliver:

On May 29th of this year, the Department purchased through the Department of Public Printing and Stationery a quantity of Pupil's Own Vocabulary Spellers, Books 1, 2 and 3. I trust you have received these books and have put them to use.

As the first half of the present academic year is about over, I am anxious to know how you found these Spellers. Are they better than the Spellers used in the past? Did the pupils like them better, etc.,?

I would appreciate it if you would let me know the views of the different teachers in this respect.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Heary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

CANADA
Office of Mr. Bernard F. Neary Superintendent Education Attention of Mr Doucet.

Dear Mr Neary:

Reference to letter under above file number dated December 15th our ent—Our teachers will compile a list of good and less valuable points on the "Our Vocabulary Spellers" when they return. Two of them have, I think, put their summaries in writing. We shall get them completed and sent within the week after re-opening of school. From what I heard of the speller it is excellent for oral composition, is considered "not complete enough" by those dealing with entrance pupils since the entrance group find a great number of words lacking in the Pupil's Own Vocabulary Spellers which words inevitably pop up on entrance examinations. But the teachers who have been very interested in this matter and who are not all agreed will send in their own findings.

Sincerely yours,

(Rev) J.R. Oliver S.J.
Principal....

REVIEW OF BOOK II

Suitability for Grades V and VI

METHOD OF STUDY:

The method of study introduced in the speller is easily followed and interesting to the pupils. My pupils enjoy reading the short stories in each exercise and finding the new words in these stories.

DICTIONARY:

The dictionary is the most interesting and productive feature in this book. Pupils soon began to consult it, without being told, for meanings and pronunciation.

KNOW YOUR WORDS:

This feature is unbeatable for correlating spelling and English. It helps the pupils to read ideas instead of words. They get a clearer understanding of words when they learn how a word is made up. The type of questions in this exercise help develop the pupil's reasoning powers.

CORRELATIONS AND PUPIL INTEREST:

Because of the wide range of topics in this book, spelling can be correlated with every subject in the course of studies. I have found it especially useful in paragraph study and story telling.

RESULTS IN SPELLING:

Using your progress chart I have found a great improvement in the pupils' ability not only to spell the words correctly but also to use the words correctly.

Teacher: E.J. McCart
Grades V VI
I find THE PUPILS' OWN VOCABULARY SPELLER

(Book 3)....a great help to supplement the old textbook.

It is performing a function that the other did not attempt as it is rather a list of words intended first of all, to have the pupil learn the spelling, word by word.

In my opinion, if used in connection with the Standard Speller, it will hasten the pupil's understanding and mastery of the words. It will then be natural to use them in composition in their proper sense.

Teacher Brother J.B. Menseau S.J.
Auxiliary teacher
Grades VII VIII
REVIEWS OF JURIST'S OWN VOCABULARY...Sellers...Bk I.

From the point of view of teacher of Ont. High School Entrance teacher; under subheadings of (a) Modern Trends (b) Pedagogical Method (c) Division of Work (Units) (d) Suitability to Ont. Course as at Present Outlined.

MODERN TRENDS: In this regard the text appears perfectly sound. The choice of words is adapted to, and chosen from the activities of our stream-lined age. The fact that pupils absorb words from the paragraph and incidentally gain a knowledge of their meaning is in keeping with "learn by doing" philosophy of Ed.

PEDAGOGICAL METHOD: Much to be commended as it makes use of problem motivation...The "KNOW YOUR WORDS SECTION" of the lesson unit, perhaps a little too long, gives the pupil skill in the application of his new words. The derivation of new words from root words, the study of vowels, diphthongs and consonants is to be highly commended. The differently stressed syllables on "desert" (noun) and desert (verb) develop skill in knowledge and use of words.

DIVISION OF WORK: Since each unit is meant to cover one week, this is rather an underestimate of ability of each child of normal age and grade. Two to three days with an active class could cover each unit.

SUITABILITY TO PRESENT ONT. COURSE: The vocabulary is not the same as is used in the modern Ont. Course as now outlined. A careful study of five years HIGH SCHOOL ENTRANCE PAPERS (based on Ont. Speller) shows that out of approximately 500 words asked on these papers with about a 70% frequency each year, 80 to 100 of these words were not listed at all.

OMISSIONS: The names of the Days of the Week, and Months of the Year, with some of their difficulties, should have been inserted. Certain common abbreviations and names of nationalities, and organizations would have been valuable.

CONCLUSION: The choice of vocabulary taken from science, progress, transportation, art, history, and sports, etc., is excellent.

CONCLUSION: The text as a whole is excellent for a supplementary text book, but not as a preparatory daily text for the Ont. H.S. Entrance examinations.

J. Sammon B.A.

Teacher Joseph Sammon B.A.
Grades VII VIII

Step 1 Clean the Surface

It is extremely important that all surfaces to be painted be thoroughly cleaned to remove all traces of grease, oil or film. Use our #1291 Thinner Cleaner, or one of the Energine type. Merely washing with soap and water is not sufficient.

Hand perspiration on the surface should be guarded against. This can be overcome by wearing thin gloves.

Step 2 Now the Design

One method is that of tracing it from a drawing or sketch. This process is easy if the object is glass; the design is then slipped inside with the paper pressed close to the surface. Scotch tape can be used to hold the design in place. It can then be used as a guide for applying the color.

On other objects, designs can be sketched lightly on the surface itself using a G8 Charcoal Marking Pencil or the softer type lead. These pencils have been designed for marking on glazed surfaces making it easy to "block in" your motif.

We recommend the use of a new hard copy paper especially made for this purpose. The sketch or actual sketch of your motif on a light weight tracing paper. The copy paper is slipped between this paper design and the surface being decorated. Then the design is traced with a hard pencil producing very sharp outlines on the surface or glass. Any tracing outline that still remains is readily wiped off with a soft cloth.

If a stencil is used it is cut with the design and attached to the surface with scotch tape.

Step 3 Apply the Colors

Note—Dek-All colors mix readily to produce other colors (blue and yellow make an attractive green, etc.) or variations of the same color. Stir the colors well before using. During the painting the brushes must be cleaned with our thinner #1291 but to avoid clogging of the brush, they should be given a final cleaning with turpentine and then washed with soap and water before putting the brushes aside for future use.

Hand Painting or Free Brush Work:

For opaque and glossy effects load your brush with color. Apply with a slow deliberate brush stroke. When the brush is nearly empty, set it aside until the next stroke is needed. Quick application of the one-stroke technique (free brush technique) results in a more transparent and less glossy appearance. In most designs it is advisable to paint the entire area with the brush, allowing it to "set" for a few minutes and then fill in the other color with a brush. This outline acts as a retaining wall for the larger areas of color.

For "Heavy Duty Use" (that is where the decorated item will be subjected to heavy usage wear) a more or less continuous wash ing is important to "flow" the colors together so that they form a smooth, even continuous coat, which can then be "polymerized" by the application of heat into one unbroken bond, as described below.

Stenciling:

Designs may be stenciled readily with ordinary stencil brushes but for more satisfactory results its achieved by using the "pad" process as this allows you to cover evenly and yet show crisp edges. Method: A piece of silk or nylon is stretched over a small pod of cotton. Spread the color thinly over a flat piece of glass or large board. Then press the silk into the desired color and apply to the surface being decorated.

Color Etching:

After the color is applied thinly and evenly it is simple to produce a transparent etched effect after the color has dried, etched lines are cut into the design with a pointed end of a pin or other sharp object. This adds to the attractiveness of the translucent effect and many variations of the above are possible.

Air Brush Painting:

These colors can be used in the air brush technique, thinning with #1291 thinner or turpentine. Especially in the case of thinning with turpentine, it is important to pre-check carefully for desired color permanency as below.

Step 4 Make it Durable

After DEK-ALL has been allowed to air dry for several days, the painted design will prove quite durable and will stand a reasonable amount of abrasion. Air drying will prove satisfactory. It is recommended that all decorative pieces such as mirrors, antiques and other surfaces not requiring constant washing and heavy handling. Warm water and mild soaps are recommended for such washings.

"Heavy Duty Use"

To produce an extra degree of permanency, finished pieces should be baked in a regular kitchen oven or kiln. Allow one hour to 24 hours. Set the decorated articles in the cold oven and allow the temperature to gradually reach 300°F. Hold this temperature for 15 minutes, then turn off the heat, allowing the painted articles to remain in the oven till cool.

An attractive range of color will be obtained both with and without the application of heat. An extreme degree of heat will cause a change in the hue of certain colors, but in the case of items to be subjected to "Heavy Duty Use," more heat is advisable than not enough, right up to the point, just below where discoloring begins.

Step 5 Many Interesting Effects

One of the most interesting ways to use the colors is to apply them on the bottom or reverse side of a glass object so that the colors are seen through the glass. This filters and softens the design and gives a wonderful two and three-dimensional effect. For example, a colored design painted on the underside of an ash tray gives it a most artistic appearance.

TRANS-MIX—By adding Trans-Mix to your colors, lovely translucent or stained glass effects can be achieved.

For ash trays or similar objects subject to hard usage an over-coating of Trans-Mix is recommended. Again heat-treat as above.

DEK-ALL Colors may be superimposed over each other, and this feature makes possible some very interesting plating and effects. By using medium value or pastel tones on dark surfaced objects attractive color effects are obtained. Less design decoration is needed when painted on dark surfaces.

THINNING COLORS—If colors stand and become thick, add a tiny bit of Dek-All Thinner (medicine dropper is recommended). Caution: Too much Thinner reduces the permanency of the colors—the less used, the better. Many customers use Trans-Mix for a similar purpose.

A Professional Tip!

Experienced craftsmen always pre-test surfaces to be painted before proceeding with production runs.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Rev. J.R. Oliver, S.J.,
Principal,
Spanish Indian Res. School,
Spanish, Ont.,

Dear Father Oliver:

I have finally reached Ottawa and have consulted our files in reference to school supplies that were requisitioned for delivery to the Spanish School.

On checking with the Department of Public Printing and Stationery they advised me that almost all of the supplies have been forwarded. Any outstanding items will be reaching you shortly.

While at Spanish I discussed general school problems with the different teachers and I made a number of notes on the requirements that the teachers brought to my attention. However, on going over my notes I find that I have my notes on the boys and girls schools confused. I am preparing one requisition for action by the Department of Public Printing and Stationery and I am sending it in care of the boys school, therefore, I would appreciate it if on receipt of these supplies you would arrange to distribute them as required.

The Supplementary readers, language books, black cover No. 285, typewriter paper, writing pads, marking ink are for the boys school. The Social Studies readers, ink wells, map of the world, duplicators, brushes, and blackboards are for the girls school. I am also forwarding fifteen hectograph workbooks. These are workbooks that should be used for the primary grades in both schools as they are adaptable by means of tearing out a page and running off the necessary copies.
In connection with the larger art paper, oil paints and pastels, the Department is working on suitable materials for this type of work, however, we are not meeting with very much success at present. As soon as we get something arranged you will be receiving your quota.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Spanish Indian Res. School,
Spanish, Ont.,

Dear Father Oliver:

In my letter of September 16th, I wrote you to the effect that we were searching for suitable art supplies and were not meeting with much success.

We have lately, however, run across an English firm that is prepared to supply pastels, large drawing paper in pads, oil paints and oil paint brushes.

On my visit to the school, the teachers in the girls section were interested in these materials for their High School pupils but I did not meet the teachers in the boys section and therefore, do not know if they are interested also.

Please prepare a requisition for the requirements of art supplies and forward it to this office in the usual manner. On receipt of this requisition we will forward you these supplies.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. J.R. Oliver, S.J.,
Principal,
Spanish Indian Res. School,
Spanish, Ont.,

Dear Father Oliver:

I have a letter from Brother Edmund O'Keeffe S.J. in reference to twenty-four bottles Marking Ink and Note Books #268.

I ordered these supplies in September. However, the Department of Public Printing and Stationery neglected to make the shipment. This morning I contacted the Stationery Branch and am informed that the books will be going out within a week.

With reference to the ink, as this is not a stock item, the Department of Public Printing and Stationery are writing the suppliers to rush delivery.

I expect you should receive these items shortly. However, if there is further delay do not hesitate to write again and the matter will be checked further.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Nov. 29th 1950

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

For the attention of Mr. Trask.

Re yours file 471-4 (E6). Nov. 10/50.

Dear Sir,

With reference to above quoted letter &
the suggestion contained in the last paragraph thereof.

The items in question (24 bottles marking Ink & 4 Note Books # 288) have not yet been received.

Thanking you for your courtesy.

Yours sincerely,

Edmund O'Keefe S.J.

P. Rev. J. R. Oliver S.J.

CANADA
December 4, 1950.

Mr. F.O. Majoie,
Administrative Officer,
Dept. of Public Printing & Stationery,
York St.,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

This refers to our requisitions 59-32865 and 59-32866 for the Spanish Indian Residential School.

The first deals with four copies of Blackbooks #288 (Stock No. 3006). The latter one refers to twenty-four 2 oz. bottles Carter's Marking Ink.

The Principal at the school informs me that these items have not been received.

Would you kindly expedite delivery and advise.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Spanish, Ont.,

Dear Father Oliver:

I have your requisition for Canadian Problem and Practice Arithmetics (Third Book) and the Manual.

I regret that the Department no longer supplies these books as they are not authorized for the Province of Ontario. We are prepared, however, to provide you with the Junior Mathematics, Book 1 for Grade 7 and Junior Mathematics, Book 2 for Grade 8 which are authorized.

Please advise whether these would be required.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Dear Mr. Tract,

The grade six set would be of value here as there is no work-book available for the Catholic text - Treasure House - and the children seem to require some such guide.

Sincere thanks for the splendid supplies you sent after your September visit. It was most useful and is much appreciated.

Dear Sir:

On November 22nd 1950 the Department of Education, Province of Saskatchewan advised this office that a duplicate payment had been made of their invoice No. B-30621 in the amount of $84.40. It has since been established that we paid this account on November 30th 1949 and that your office paid this same account by your cheque No. DE2-77206 on November 24th 1949.

A request was made by this office to the Saskatchewan Book Bureau to refund you the amount of $84.40. A cheque has now been received and I am pleased to enclose same herewith (Cheque No. 9242). Reverend Sir:

We are preparing to move to our new quarters and naturally on such occasions certain articles crop up than can be dispensed with. We have a number of books that we thought might be useful to the pupils of your school. Some of these will be for the boys' clubroom, others could probably be passed over to the girls' school and still others could be used for the primary groups. Some you may find will be of very little use. We know that you will be able to make the best of these articles, hence the reason for sending them.

DEPARTMENT OF CITIZENSHIP AND IMMIGRATION
INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH

OTTAWA, March 22, 1951.

Rev. J.R. Oliver,
Spanish Indian Res. School,
Spanish, Ont.,

Gentlemen:

This is to acknowledge receipt of your Invoice No. Sept. 25/51 amounting to $36.79.

Please be advised that we are forwarding this invoice to the Department of Public Printing and Stationery who are responsible for the purchase of books and stationery, instructing the said office to pay this account. Our Order number is 59-33824. For any further correspondence this number should be quoted.

It is expected a cheque for the above-mentioned amount should reach you shortly.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Acting Superintendent of Education.

Spanish, Ontario

May 9, 1951.

Miss Z. St. James,
Principal,
Spanish Indian Res. School,
Spanish, Ont.,

Dear Miss St. James:

With reference to your letter of May 7th regarding the yellow claim forms, you are advised that the forms you have received are the forms in use now, as the forms you used in the past have been revised.

You are obliged to forward a copy of the yellow and white form to Ottawa. For your copy you may use one or the other or simply use a clear sheet of paper.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

September 11, 1951.

Mr. R.P.G. Laurence,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.,

It has come to my attention when checking the Department of Public Printing and Stationery accounts that ten copies of "The Story of Canada" were shipped in error to the Spanish C.E. Indian Day School. Only one copy of this book was required.

It would be appreciated if you would arrange to ship nine copies of this book to Father Oliver, Principal, Spanish Indian Residential School as they are required there.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Indian Residential School
Spanish, Ontario
October 11, 1951

Education Department
Indian Affairs Branch
Dept. of Citizenship
and Immigration
Ottawa, Ontario
Attention: Mr. Drake

Dear Sir:

During your visit here in September, we ordered writing books from you. These books just arrived, but there seems to be a mistake in the number ordered and the number received. Enclosed is the invoice received in the shipment, and also the list containing the number of books ordered.

Would you please see what can be done about this as soon as possible, as we have been awaiting the arrival of this shipment of books since your visit.

Yours truly,

J. P. Murphy
November 2nd/51

INDIAN AFFAIRS

Mr P. Phelan
Supt Education
Indian Affairs Branch Ottawa.

Dear Mr Phelan,

May we have more forms for the Class Monthly Report of the Training Division for our Mechanics report... Manual training. We are out of them.

Sincerely

(Rev) J.R. Oliver S.J.
Principal

Aug. 31, 1952.

Mr. Philip Phelan
Supt. of Education
Dept. of Cit. & Immigration
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

It is impossible for me to complete the annual report for the school year ending June 30, 1952, until the boys return for elementary school. I cannot find some of the information requested, and this I shall be able to obtain from the boys. I shall send the report in as soon as possible after the opening of the school year.

You mentioned that you could obtain maps for me. We need at least three (3) sets of maps for each continent, one of the world, one of Canada and one of the British Isles.

In the requisition sent in last Spring, apparently not enough requests were made for several texts. I have made a thorough check on all texts and we need the following texts:

Disraeli (13) Silas Marner (20)
Ivanhoe (15) English Highway (40)

I don't know if it is possible to obtain these texts at this late date, but I would appreciate it very much if you could do something.

We are busy preparing for the arrival of the boys. I hope to have everything under control before very long.

I shall be looking forward to seeing you on your next visit.

Yours Sincerely,

Father Wm. P. Maurice S.J.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES  
CANADA
Sept. 19, 1952.

Mr. Philip Phelan  
Superintendent of Education  
Department of Education  
Indian Affairs Branch  
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

In this letter, I am sending you a list of books and equipment. It may seem rather large, but in checking our supplies I have found that these are necessary and that we do not have either enough or that the copies we have are not usable or that we just have no copies. For instance, I am running into added difficulties because of the new Latin for Secondary schools. We are using everything we have and as a result some of the classes have the old and some the new and the two differ considerably. Mr. Sammon made out the list of English texts he needs and said that he would have put them on the requisition of last Spring if he had had the courses of study at hand.

If you think the whole list cannot be filled will you please advise me of what you think are not necessary.

I am including a list of vocational guidance material I think I need. Mr. Taylor of the Vocational Guidance Department of the Department of Education listed only the essential requirements.

The annual Report for last year will be sent to you shortly.

Trusting to hear from you soon, I am

Yours Sincerely,

Rev. Wm. P. Maurice S.J.  
(Dean of Studies)
Ottawa, 29 September 1952

Geo. L. Ward,
Books & Publications Section.

Oct. 31, 1952.

Order No. A61642 - Spanish Indian Residential School.
2 copies each Using our Language - Grades 6 and 7 - out of stock reprinted.

Yours sincerely,

October 27th, 1952.

Department of Public Printing and Stationery,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sirs:

This will acknowledge receipt of the following orders from you: A 61198, A 61712, and A 61642 which have had our attention and which have been filled as far as possible.

We regret that we could not include the following for the reasons indicated:

Order No. A 61712 - Oeids No. 2 Indian Day School 12 copies
Using our Language - Grade 4 - out of stock - reprinting

Order No. A 61198 - Georgina Island Indian Day School 4 copies
General Science, Book 1 - this title is now temporarily out of print. We could substitute the new Science text for this Grade if you wish. General Science - Intermediate - Book 3 - published at $2.15.

4 copies Britain's Story - out of stock for about one week
4 copies Using our Language - which grade? The only text available in this Series at the moment is the Grade 3 text - with the exception of Grade IX. Is this the text you require?

Order No. A 61642 - Spanish Indian Residential School.
2 copies each Using our Language - Grades 6 and 7 - out of stock
reprinted
2 copies Using our Language - which grade do you required this text for?

Yours sincerely,

J.M. DENT & SONS (CANADA) LTD

Spanish, Ontario

INDIAN AFFAIRS

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education,
Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.,

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Re: Requisition for Elementary Text Books.
"Using Our Language".

With reference to yours of November 4,
under file number 471-4 (E6), our original request was for two
copies of each.

Junior Division - Book 3 for Grade 6
Intermediate Division - Book 1 for Grade 7
Intermediate Division - Book 2 for Grade 8

However, if it is possible and you approve,
I would like to have the complete set as we have no copies
of this set and it is the only authorized text for composition
from Grades 3 to 8.

The set consists of:

Primary Division - Book 1 for Grade 3
Junior Division - Books 1, 2, 3 for Grades 4, 5 & 6.
Intermediate Division - Books 1 & 2 for Grades 7 & 8.

In Grade 9 and 10 we are using the "Junior
School English Course" and "An English Highway" which you
have already sent us.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Rev. C.N. Rushman, S.J.,
Principal,
Spanish Indian Res. School,
Spanish, Ont.,

Dear Father Rushman:

Please be advised that we are asking the Department of Public Printing and Stationery to ship to you one set of Encyclopedia of Canada. This Encyclopedia is a set of six books. The information in these books was compiled by the association of more than one hundred leading Canadian specialists and authorities in every branch of knowledge. The information is authoritative, practical and non-technical.

These books were ordered for your school for use by the senior elementary school pupils and the high school pupils. It would be appreciated if you would put these books into use as soon as you receive them and advise after a lapse of six months as to the suitability of these books for Indian schools.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Residential School
Spanish, Ontario

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Along with the monthly report I would like to convey the thanks of Father Maurice and myself for the supplies and especially for the typewriter which you have sent us.

Father Maurice brought to my attention two items on the stationery requisition:

1) - 100 pkgs. of small blotters, Cat. No. 4001 were requisitioned and the packing slip lists 100. However, 320 pkgs. were sent. I presume that we shall keep these rather than send back the extras.

2) - 6 Stamp Pads Blue No. 1, Cat. No. 4133 were requisitioned and listed on the packing slip. Only two were enclosed.

I hope all is going well. I shall probably be seeing you in the near future.

Yours Truly,

Rev. C. N. Rushman, S.J.
March 9, 1953.

Rev. C.N. Rushman, S.J.,
Principal,
Spanish Indian Res. School,
Spanish, Ont.,

Dear Father Rushman:

With reference to your letter of March 3rd regarding supplies for the Spanish Indian Residential School, we have contacted the Department of Public Printing and Stationery and they admit that there were errors made when filling the order.

With reference to the blotters, it would be appreciated if you would return the 220 packets of these blotters to:

Dept. of Public Printing & Stationery,
47 Clarence St.,
Ottawa.

You should send these blotters collect.

With reference to the stamp pads, the Department of Public Printing and Stationery has agreed to ship the four pads outstanding.

With reference to the last paragraph of your letter, I will be glad to see you when you visit Ottawa, however, I must point out that I will be away from the office from March 17 to 20 inclusive.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
March 20, 1953.

Rev. C.H. Rushman, S.J.,
Principal,
Spanish Indian Res. School,
Spanish, Ont.,

Dear Father Rushman:

With reference to our letter of March 9th, please be advised that we have received two cartons of the blotters which were transferred to the Department of Public Printing and Stationery. The Queen's Printer advises that ninety packets of blotters were in the two cartons.

If you will refer to our letter of March 9th you will note that you were requested to return the 220 packets of these blotters to the Department of Public Printing and Stationery, 47 Clarence Street.

Please advise whether you are returning the remainder of the blotters or have you put them to use at the Spanish Residential School. For your information the Department has not been billed for the 220 packets of the blotters. If the 130 packets of the blotters will be used in the Spanish School, please advise as arrangements will have to be made for the Department to pay for these.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Department of Public Printing & Stationery,
OTTAWA,
Ontario.
Dear Sirs:

We have received from you your Order No. 59-11179 which calls for 14 copies of MODERN HISTORY.

Before sending this order we wish to draw your attention to the fact that "Modern History" in its present form will not be the authorized Grade 12 textbook in Ontario next year. It will be replaced by a revised book tentatively entitled WORLD HISTORY, Volume II. We can supply our present book if you so desire but we are giving you the opportunity of cancelling this order if you find it advisable. We shall keep your order in our follow-up file until we hear from you.

Ottawa, January 27th, 1922.

Dear Sirs,

Kindly furnish me with the names of firms from whom prices may be obtained for laundry machinery required for the Spanish River Industrial School.

Yours truly,

F.H. Paget
Accountant and Purchasing Agent.

The Purchasing Commission of Canada,
Ottawa, Ont.
MEMORANDUM,

MR. PAGET,

Will you kindly furnish me with names of firms from whom prices may be obtained for the following laundry machinery required for the Spanish River Industrial School:

1 - 36" x 54" washer,
1 - 26" solid curb extractor,
1 - 66" flat work ironer,
1 - garment press.

Architect.
January 24, 1922

Memorandum:

The Honourable
The Acting Superintendent General

We desire to install in the laundries of the Kenora Indian Boarding School and the Spanish River Industrial School certain laundry equipment, as follows: a washer, extractor and electric motor in the Kenora School, at an estimated cost of $1,400.00; a washer, extractor and flat ironer in the Spanish River School, at an estimated cost of $1,800.00. This machinery will, of course, be purchased in accordance with the rules and regulations of the Purchasing Commission. Funds are available from the vote for Indian Education.

I would ask your authority for the expenditure.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Dear Sir,

Re Laundry Machinery

Enclosed please find the rough sketch asked for in your letter of the 18th instant.

As to the size of washer, extractor etc., I beg to say that a washer 36" x 54", such as the "Sterilizing Washer" illustrated in the Canadian Laundry Catalogue, page 84, would be most welcome.

A solid cast reflector, as shown on pages 48 and 49 in the same catalogue;

One steam boiler, belt driven hotwater drum, 66";

One Universal Press Drum; if cheaper, one garment press ought to do just as well; the cheapest and simplest would do well for us; these four pieces would be sufficient for the space we dispose of in those three rooms which are allotted to laundry work. As the students have to learn how to work at home, we shall have to keep a few wash tubs for that purpose.

Your obedient servant,

V. Grant, S.S. Principal
Industrial School,
Spanish Ont.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

TWO MACHINES IN ONE!

The Prosperity Palm Beach and Wool Combination

In the Prosperity, you have a properly padded ironing head which is used only for ironing and the lower buck is used for steaming. That is why you get a bone dry garment with lasting crease but without shine. Other machines try to have the upper head do two things at once, steam and iron, and the result is that it does neither so the garment is not properly ironed or properly steamed.

This machine is also provided with a highly polished nickeled upper ironing head, and is used by thousands of cleaners for ironing Palm Beach suits, silks and general work other than woolens.

THE PROSPERITY COMPANY, Inc., SYRACUSE, N.Y.
Two 38-inch Prosperity Presses in Tandem

Traq-Prosperity Presses may be combined in a tandem unit as a combination of any two machines; one releases while the other locks.
Follow the arrows in the above cut of the Prosperity Garment Press and you can readily trace the movement of the steam through the ironing head, buck, separator, condenser, and back to the main return.

This is our positive circulating system which insures uniform and ample heat at all times. The steam is taken from the intake pipe and passes through one side of the flexible joint and goes directly to the highest point in the ironing head. The steam fills the upper buck forcing out all dead air and condensation and then passes into the opposite side of the swivel steam joint.

It passes from there into the highest chamber of the lower buck, and after gravitating to the lower chambers it passes into the separator. All condensation and air are carried direct into the return line. You can see that the heating principle of the Prosperity Garment Press is one perfect unit,—in other words, our system is a two-pipe system through which all steam must pass. This positive circulating system makes possible a vapor vacuum which enables us to draw steam through the ironing head at such speed and with such force that it is practically impossible for any condensation to take place in the ironing head.
This view shows the flexible steam joint of the Prosperity Garment Press.

The arrows indicate the intake and return of the steam through the same joint.

Springs on the side show how contraction and expansion of steam packing is automatically taken care of, thereby positively eliminating leaks.
This is a very important factor in the heating system of the Prosperity Garment Press. This invention is decidedly unique as both intake and return are embodied in one joint, so constructed that steam is drawn and forced through one passage and out another passage as shown in the illustration.

Note the space for taking up on joint which is sufficient to make your packing last a very long time under severe usage—because you get the maximum efficiency of your packing.

This joint is really "the lungs" of the Prosperity Garment Press, as the steam is drawn and forced through one passage into the machine and through the other passage in coming out.

---

**THE PROSPERITY PRESSURE MECHANISM**

The development of a simple toggle and lever construction which will lock while the toggle joint is "on center" is a marked step forward in making the pressing machine a popular machine with the employees, as it eliminates jar and rebound and avoids wasted effort.

"On center" is the position for a toggle joint at which it will exert its greatest possible pressure; mechanical science proves that this is true and, furthermore, proves that the position "before center" and the position "beyond center" gives undeveloped pressure in the former case and diminished pressure in the latter case. The Prosperity Press has a latch which locks in perfect synchronism with the position of the toggle joint when "on center" and holds it there until the machine is released by operator.

The feature of synchronizing the locking function of the lock mechanism with the "on center" position of the toggle joint is patentable and an exclusive Prosperity feature. Other presses, although they may have complicated leverage or cam systems for controlling pressure do not have this synchronized action, and the result is insufficient pressure either on account of locking "before center" or wasted effort plus insufficient pressure by reason of going "beyond center." Complicated leverage and cam systems wear quickly and soon lose whatever degree of efficiency they may have originally possessed.

How well the Prosperity aim "the simplest is always the best" has here, too, succeeded can best be told by the operators who benefit by this wonderful design and prefer working on the Prosperity machine. Jar and rebound are eliminated which means the minimum of wear on the press combined with ease of operation.
The ironing head of the Prosperity Press is perfectly balanced by means of equalized weights. Of course, spring tension is also provided on either side of the swinging arm so as to bring in any of the finer adjustments required by the individual operator or by the particular class of work, and the result is that this balanced construction adds wonderfully to the popularity of this press with the employees.

The ratio of leverage on the Prosperity Garment Press combined with the simplified single toggle joint construction gives to this machine greater pressure than is possible in other presses. The ratio on this machine is one to eleven which is over 52% more than any other on the market.

This combination of single toggle joint construction and simple leverage is the most efficient it has been possible for mechanical engineers to devise. It eliminates over 65% of moving parts used on older type machines and that means a minimum of trouble and upkeep cost.

THREE-POINT SUSPENSION

When you have material of varying thickness to iron you need flexibility in the press, and this is insured to you in the Prosperity Garment Press. Compensation of the ironing head is automatically taken care of through the novel three-point suspension of the head on the yoke. Because of this construction the machine will allow for the thickness in the long way of ironing as well as the narrow way. This is not true of other presses.

It is an admitted fact that three-point bearing or suspension will adjust itself to an uneven surface with a great deal more flexibility than any other construction.
With this fact in mind the designers of Prosperity Garment Press worked out the plans so that we have a three point suspension of the legs, three-point suspension of steam separator to table, three-point suspension of the lower buck to the steam separator and a three-point suspension of the upper buck to the yoke.

The combining of these several items of three-point suspension, and the novel method of applying the three-point suspension to the upper buck, gives to the Prosperity Garment Press a flexibility not possessed by the older types of machines.

Note the size and weight of frame which will absolutely withstand any quantity of work the machine might be expected to do covering a period of many years. Also note the balanced construction; the head and counterweight are evenly balanced so that practically a typewriter touch will start the motion either up or down.

Note that it possesses strength, where strength counts. Note that there is nothing complicated about its mechanism and remember that in machinery the fewer the parts the stronger the machine.

Each and every part of the Prosperity Press is accessible—interchangeable—replaceable, but the wearing parts are so few that the first expense is practically the last.

SPECIFICATIONS

Length of ironing head, 39 inches; width at large end, 13½ inches; width at small end, 8½ inches; floor space, front to back, 53 inches, left to right, 56 inches; weight, 950 pounds.

Toronto Standard Flat Work Ironer

The cut on the opposite page shows our "TORONTO" STEAM-HEATED ROTARY FLAT WORK IRONER, which is recognized as a favorite with public Laundries, Hotels and Institutions. It has a steam cylinder 16 inches in diameter running in combination with three auxiliary padded rolls, covered with heavy wool covering, which absorbs the moisture and protects the hems of the goods. The machine presents a radiating surface of from 2500 to 5000 square inches (according to length of cylinder), sufficient to dry and iron the goods taken directly from the extractor.

The gears are covered with shields and safety guard on feeding side, so arranged as to reduce all possible danger to a minimum.

An especially desirable feature of this machine is that the steam inlet and drain are, by an improved device, both at one end of machine. We guarantee by this improved device on trap system to be freer of condensation than any other Mangle on the market today.

The advantages of this feature render it by far the most desirable Mangle every offered to public Laundries, Hotels, and Institutions.

The construction of this Mangle throughout is of the best material, including cut gears, steel shaft, and is finished in nickel and brass.

This machine has been so improved that the auxiliary rolls are all driven from one large gear on end of cylinder, doing away with the train of gears on end of Mangle opposite driving end, thereby removing all unequal strain. These machines are all properly adjusted and tested before leaving our factory.

The machine operates with a single belt, and is started or stopped by means of a lever operated clutch. In addition to these safety devices above mentioned, the pressure is applied to the roll by means of a lever, and this pressure is relieved and the rolls drop free of each other by merely moving this lever a few inches.
Starch Extractor

This Starch Extractor is designed to remove surplus starch from dipped goods, by centrifugal force. The basket controlling mechanism and the basket are similar to those of our Solid Curb Extractors previously described. The outer shell is of heavy copper, tempered on the inside and is detachable. It is but a moment's work to take off the shell.

When this is removed every portion of the basket is entirely accessible and may be thoroughly and quickly cleaned. This extractor is durable, easy to keep clean and will prove useful in any laundry. It is made in two sizes, with either detached or attached counter-shaft. Belt or motor driven.

20-inch Basket

The countershaft should make 440 revolutions per minute. The tight and loose pulleys on countershaft are 6 inches, with 3 inch face. Floor space, 28x15 inches. Weight, 650 pounds.

24-inch Basket

The countershaft should make 400 revolutions per minute. The tight and loose pulleys on the countershaft are 8 inches in diameter, with 3 inch face. Floor space, 33 x 41 inches. Weight, 1,000 pounds.
Imperial Washer

This is our special washer designed to carry the heaviest kind of a load with the least amount of belt power, and it is so constructed that this machine can be turned over with a belt one-quarter of the size that is used on what is termed the ordinary Standard Washing Machine.

In construction it is similar to all of our other washers, the outside shell being made of the very best grade of clear cypress, 2-inch stock. It is made with either iron or wood heads, but preferably of wood, as while there has been a great demand for iron heads in the past, the expense is not warranted where machines are made with self-supporting iron end frames, as used in all of our different types of machines.

The inside cylinder is made regularly from clear heart stock yellow pine, but can be furnished in maple, when desired.

The Automatic Reverse Movement is simplicity itself and absolutely positive in its reversing action.

All loose pulleys are fitted with grease cups, while tight pulleys, pinions and gears are accurately key-seated. Every feature of this machine is of the very highest type and we invite comparison with other makes.
Brass Washer Cylinders

These are made in diameters of 3½" and 4½" and in lengths of 12", 18", 24", and 36". Brass cylinders are not carried in stock, as most work of this kind is special and, therefore, we prefer to build to specifications.

We can furnish these cylinders in either numbers 12 or 13 half hard brass and with any number of file desired.

The catches and locks on door are of very simple form; of ample width and so arranged that new springs can be easily inserted. The hinges are extra heavy and are so arranged that when the door closes it laps under the back of the cylinder and takes the strain off of the hinge pins.

Cylinders are made with or without par- tition and with one or more doors, and the door can be made full length of the cylinder when desired, but poorer to manufacture as shown in the cut, as this style of construction lends stability to the cylinder.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
THE BEAVER SOAP CO. LIMITED
"EVERYTHING FOR THE STEAM LAUNDRY"
TORONTO CANADA

February 9th, 1922.

Mr. F. W. Paget,
Purchasing Agent, Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa —— Ontario.

Dear Sir:

We have tendered on the Laundry Equipment for the Spanish River Industrial School, but possibly our tender will require a little explanation.

We have heretofore been selling exclusively the Toronto Laundry Machine Co. Limited's machinery but unfortunately, owing to the death of the President of that Company, Mr. John O'Reilly, M.P., the Laundry Machine business has been disposed of to the Canadian Laundry Machinery Co. Limited, and we have, therefore, been compelled to get other Agencies. We have made an agreement with the Lutes-Similair Co. of Benton Harbor, Michigan, to sell their machinery temporarily. This machinery ranks highest for quality and durability. We sold a large number of their machines in the West some years ago and they have given wonderful satisfactions. We have also changed from the Canadian Hoff-Man Company's Presses to the Prosperity Press because these machines showed so great superiority over any other make of Press that we have examined.

Now, the arrangements mentioned above are only temporary. It is our intention, if we can make the necessary arrangements, to manufacture a high grade line of Laundry Machinery ourselves. This will be much to the benefit of everyone interested in Laundry Machinery including your selves, as otherwise there would be absolutely no competitive firm in Canada to the Canadian Laundry Machinery Co. It will, however, take us two or three months to get on a producing basis, and in the meantime would ask you to give consideration to the tender we have placed herewith, and we can assure you that the machinery quoted on this is absolutely first class and made by reputable firms of long standing.

Yours very truly,

THE BEAVER SOAP CO. Limited

[Signature]

Vice President.

HLH.W.
Ottawa, February 13, 1922.

Dear Sirs,

With reference to your tender submitted for laundry machinery for the Spanish River Industrial School, under date of January the 3rd, it is noted that the prices quoted are f. o. b. Toronto, Ont. The form submitted to you with reference to this machinery asked for prices f. o. b. Spanish, Ont., and I would ask that you furnish me with a tender for the machinery f. o. b. Spanish, Ont. I would also ask that you advise me if all of the machines which you propose to furnish are manufactured in Canada.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sirs:

Memorandum:

The Acting Superintendent General

We desire to install in the laundries of the Kenora Indian Boarding School and the Spanish River Industrial School certain laundry equipment, as follows: a washer, extractor and electric motor in the Kenora School, at an estimated cost of $1,400.00; a washer, extractor and flat ironer in the Spanish River School, at an estimated cost of $1,800.00. This machinery will, of course, be purchased in accordance with the rules and regulations of the Purchasing Commission. Funds are available from the vote for Indian Education.

Dear Sirs:

We are in receipt of your most esteemed favor of the 20th inst. and we wish to extend our many many thanks for this valuable order. We assure you that we will give you entire satisfaction. Dear Sir,

EXD

Please find enclosed a list of items for the new Laundry Machine ordered by the Dept. and shipped to the Spanish Industrial School.

The last one arrives next week. They are not installed yet; and it may take some time yet because we plan to build a concrete cement floor for the Boiler and Steam Pipes and then set the machines before we can remove the old system of wash tubs without disturbing the nearby work shop. The whole work will be done by ourselves and we are now in a very busy time. When they arrive, we are very grateful.

Would you kindly convey our thanks to those who have worked with such generosity in favour of this school? It will be much appreciated by the Laundry Dept.

All the members of the staff, of both houses wish to express their thanks to the Dept. of Indian Affairs for this generous aid given to the Spanish Industrial School.

V. Grant, Principal
Spanish Industrial School

UNIVERSITY OF OTTAWA
Ottawa, Ont., February 14th, 1923.

Personal to the Architect

The Secretary,
Dept of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Please find enclosed account in connection with the installation of laundry machinery at Spanish (St Joseph's) Industrial School.

An account including material and work has already been presented to the Department but objection was raised on the ground that the School authorities should at least provide the labor. The Principal acknowledging the generosity of the Department in supplying the machinery has returned me the account minus the labor and part of the material. I therefore hope that payment will be made without difficulty.

You will note that competitive prices were not asked for as they would have considerably delayed the installation. Moreover, a detailed list of material could not be prepared at one time. Finally, the engineer had to make a personal choice of all fittings and accessories.

I heartily recommend to the Department of this account as this action will complement the Department's generous grant in the instance.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 1)
October 25, 1923.

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

From time to time, as funds were available, different Indian residential schools have received an increase in pupilage. I am strongly in favour of granting such increases, when possible, if the required accommodation is available in the individual institutions already existing dormitories. I believe it to be in the interest of economy for both Department and Churches if we fill the existing residential schools to the limit of their accommodation. I am pleased to report that for the fiscal year ended March 1923, there were on the roll at residential schools a total of 5847 pupils - an increase of 564 in the past two years.

I have had a lengthy discussion with the Rev. Father J. B. Smith, S.J., the new incumbent at the Spanish Residential School, and I have urged upon him the acceptance of pupils up to the limit of his accommodation. He has made a report since his return to the school, and is willing to accept 112 boys and a like number of girls - a total of 224, or an increase of 54. Air space in dormitories and classrooms is more than sufficient for the added number of pupils.

The Rev. Principal understands that, if we increase the pupilage, the institution will open its doors to the orphan and destitute children of Gaugamela, St. Regis and Oks. Last year the Rev. Father Arnot hindered the Department's efforts to place our wards from these reserves in the Spanish School, in spite of the fact that certain cases were very urgent.

In view of the new Principal's readiness to meet the Department's wishes, I shall be pleased to have your authority to grant his request that we increase the pupilage to 224 by purchase for the institution 54 beds, complete with mattresses (expense in connection with the purchase estimated $180).

I should also be pleased to have your authority to supply five sewing machines to this school. The Rev. Principal has asked for eight. There is no record that the Department has ever supplied sewing machines to the Spanish School. These five machines will cost in the neighborhood of $310.

Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. Sir:

Mr. Scott,

I shall be pleased to have your authority to purchase a typewriter for the use of the Spanish Indian Residential School. The new principal, Rev. Father Sauve, is instituting several changes at the school and is desirous of having, not only typed communications for the Department, but copies for his own file. The institution's finances are, I believe, not in good condition at the present time and I beg to recommend that his request for a typewriter be granted.

Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sirs,

In the past years the prefects with the boys have made a skating ring using barrels and pails carrying the water from a distance about 150 feet. This year we have installed a tank and a pipe 150 feet long to bring the water near the skating ring. Now the boys and especially the prefects would be most grateful to yourself and to your department if you could send them 150 ft. rubber hose 1½ in. inside diameter to spread the water on the ring.

Hoping that your Department will kindly grant us that new request,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Replying to your letter of the 11th instant, quoting on the fire hose required for delivery at Spanish, Ont., I beg to inform you that your quotation for the supplying of the hose required is accepted.

Please arrange to ship, as soon as possible, addressed to Rev. J. B. Sauve, Principal, Indian Residential School, Spanish, Ont., 150' - 16" "Flax Tow" Underwriters Unlined Linen Hose. This hose should be supplied at the price quoted by you, viz: 16 cents per foot, subject to a special discount of 10%.

Please forward your account, in duplicate, to Rev. Father Sauve, who is being informed that the order has been placed with you, and requested, upon receipt of the hose, to certify the account and forward it to the Department, when payment will be made.

We do not require any couplings with the above hose.

Please acknowledge receipt of this order and state date when shipment will be made.

Yours very truly,

F. H. Paget,
Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

Gutta Percha & Rubber, Limited,
219 Sparks St.,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, December 17, 1923.

Rev. Sir:

Replying to your request to be supplied with 150' of rubber hose to be used in connection with the rink at the Spanish Indian Residential School, I beg to inform you that we are today placing an order with the Gutta Percha & Rubber Limited, Ottawa, to ship addressed to you, Spanish, Ont., 150' - 14" "Flax Tow" Underwriters Unlined Linen Hose.

The above firm have been requested to make early shipment and to forward their account, in duplicate, to you. Upon receipt of the hose, if in good condition, you should certify on this account that the goods have been received and that the prices charged are fair and just, and return them to the Department, in order that payment can be made.

We hope that when the hose arrives it will be satisfactory for the purpose for which it is required.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

Dear Sirs,

Our boys and especially our prefects are most thankful to yourself and to your department for the 150 feet of fire hose, for the skating ring, which we have received in good order.

Most gratefully yours,

[Signature]
J. B. [Name]
Principal
Spanish April, 28th. 1924

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,

Dear Sir,

Our Prefects and our pupils would be most thankful to your Department if you could send us a whole set of Baseball gloves with masks and protectors for a club of boys about 15 years of age. We would also need a dozen of footballs for boys and girls, this being the main amusement during the short recreation; also 2 Punching Bags and a complete tennis outfit for the girls.

As we are doing all we can to make our pupils love the school we have decided to form a brass band. We all know the good influence band has had in Qu'Appelle and Wikwemikong and other places. Our pupils are really well disposed presently and we are trying our best to keep them in good spirit and attach them to the school; since last August, we are happy to say that not a single pupil ran away from school.

Three benefactors have given us:
2 second hand Cornets, 2 Eb. Altos, 1 Slide Trombone, 1 Bb Basses

If your Department could provide us few more instruments it would naturally mean a great help and a great encouragement to us.

I remain,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Messrs. Ketchum & Co.,

Ottawa, April 30th, 1924.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 25th instant, requesting that the playground equipment mentioned by you be supplied for the use of the Spanish Indian Residential School, as well as a few instruments for the band which is being organised among the pupils.

In reply I beg to say that we are placing an order here for 6 footballs and 2 volley ball equipments. One volley ball equipment is being supplied for the boys and one for the girls. This game is greatly enjoyed by pupils of Indian schools. I may say that the Department does not supply baseball outfits to residential schools. We are not prepared to supply the punching bags and tennis outfit.

Regarding the band instruments, I beg to say that there are no funds specially provided for the purchase of equipment of this nature. I shall be pleased, however, if you will furnish a list of the instruments which you require and the approximate cost of the same. Consideration would be given to the providing of funds necessary to purchase the same in next year's appropriation.

The 6 footballs and 2 volley ball equipments mentioned above are all the Department is prepared to provide at the present time.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Ottawa, June 30th, 1924.

Rev. Sir,

Mr. Agent Letourneau, of Caughnawaga, has forwarded a letter which Frank Labache, a pupil of the Spanish Residential School, sent to his sister requesting that he be supplied with a glass eye to replace the one which he had broken. In this connection I have to request that you will arrange to have this boy fitted with a glass eye. It might be well, at the same time, to obtain an extra eye which could be used to replace any damage. It may be necessary to have this boy sent to Sudbury or the Soo to an optician. If so, no unnecessary expense should be incurred. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to have the boy fitted with a glass eye and at the lowest possible cost. You should furnish properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost of the eye and also for any expense which may be incurred in taking the boy to an optician.

This matter should receive your early attention, and I shall be pleased to hear as to what action you have taken to have the work done.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. J. B. Sauve, S. J.,
Principal, Spanish Res. School,
Spanish, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 1)
August 21st, 1924.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I would point out that a large number of the desks at present in the Spanish Boys' School were brought here from Wikwemikong, while others have since been built at the school. They have been in constant use for many years and are worn out. We would need seating accommodation, single desks, especially for 60 of the older boys as follows:

10 rows with 5 seats in each row
also 10 rears and 6 fronts for pupils aged as follows:
10 for pupils 10 to 12
35 " 12 " 14
15 " 15 " 17

The above will improve the appearance of the class room as urgently needed; single desks are a great help for discipline and would render the teacher's task easier in class.

It would be of a great assistance to the School if they were supplied by the Department.

I would be pleased to receive them as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal

SPANISH, Ont.

August 29th, 1924

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Rev. Fr. Sauve praised so much your kindness towards our Institution that I dare to ask again.

We need hardly table knives and forks and cups.

Would it be possible to have these items supplied by your Department? If you can, I will let you know what I need and how many.

I remain,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 1)
Ottawa, September 3rd, 1924.

Rev. Sir:

Replying to letter of the 21st ultimo from the former Principal of the Spanish Indian Residential School requesting that desks be supplied for the use of 60 pupils, I beg to inform you that an order is today being placed with the Globe Furniture Co. Ltd., Waterloo, Ont., to ship addressed to you the number and sizes as per the enclosed copy of order to them.

This firm have been requested to forward their account, in duplicate, to you, and upon receipt of the desks, if in good condition, you should certify thereon that the desks have been received in good condition and that the prices charged are fair and just. You should then forward the account to the department, in order that payment can be made.

The desks should be set up in ten rows, with 5 desks and a front and rear seat to each row. Sufficient desks are supplied to provide seating accommodation for 60 pupils.

It is hoped that when these desks arrive they will be satisfactory and provide ample seating accommodation for the senior room in the boys' school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. Chas. Belanger,
Principal, Indian Res. School,
Spanish, Ont.

Account & Purchasing Agent,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

We thank you for your order #36-0-5 covering New Globe Automatic Single Desks, cherry color woods, to be shipped to the Indian Residential School, Spanish, Ontario, o/c Rev. Charles Belanger, S.J., Principal.

We will make shipment of these desks the early part of next week.

Again thanking you, we are,

Yours very truly,

THE GLOBE FURNITURE CO. LIMITED

J. Bahnson
General Manager
The building has three stories above a basement that is at least 10 ft above the ground. There is a central stairway and one inside at one end. They have ropes at the upstairs windows but in case of fire they would be useless for girls. Their only means of escape would be the end stairway and this is above the kitchen they would be cut off in case of fire.

A fire escape at one end along with wide with a hand rail on each side so that the girls could descend two abreast would be satisfactory. The height inside each room on each story is about 12 ft. Such a fire escape would be around 45 ft or maybe a little more. This however is only a rough estimate.

There is nothing like a fire escape in case of fire. If such an escape happened the inside present conditions of it commenced in the basement on the west end of the house the occupants would be caught as in a trap. The dormitories on the top floor.

The corporation is now in debt in their effort to educate and train Indian girls and I feel that the Department should assist at least in the erection of a fire escape at least end the building. The long central corridor on each floor would lead to it and all would be set at rest.

I feel this is urgent as any confusion even the least would also mean grave concern if a fire resulted.

I feel that you will consider it favorably.

J.M. Bennett

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 1)
Extract from Inspector's Report on the SPANISH RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, September 4, 1924.

I have been encouraging a fire escape to be placed on at least one end of this building as they have an inside stair on the other end as well as a centre stair. The expense of carrying the school plant has already placed the corporation in quite a debt and they simply cannot afford the money for a fire escape. I and the Department as well as the corporation would be severely criticized in case of disaster. Could not the Department at least help toward the cost?

J. M. Bennett,
Insp.
Ottawa, Sept. 19, 1924.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, with reference to cutlery at the Spanish Indian Residential School. I regret to inform you that replacements for this type of equipment are not made by the Department.

I have to inform you that Mr. Inspector Bennett has drawn the attention of the Department to the advisability of providing a fire escape at one end of the girls' building. I should be pleased if you would make enquiries as to the most suitable and economical equipment and submit a report to the Department with an estimate as to the probable cost.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. Chas. Bélanger, S. J.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Spanish, Ont.

Ottawa, Sept. 30, 1924.

Reverend Sir:

Relative to conversation with you today, regarding the providing of fire escapes for the girls' building at the Spanish Indian Residential School, I have to say that you may arrange for the installation of a fire escape of the type suggested by you. You should purchase to the best advantage locally the material required in the building of platforms and sliding poles. Please keep proper time sheets, in duplicate, for the labour employed. A supply of forms for the purpose is sent you herewith. You should obtain accounts, in duplicate, for the material used and certify thereon that "the material was received and the prices charged fair and just." You will forward the accounts for the material and labour to the Department, when payment will be made. The total cost of the fire escape should not exceed, if possible, your estimate of approximately $200.

When this fire escape is completed and tested by the pupils and staff as to its suitability, the question of providing an adequate number for the use of both boys' and girls' buildings will be considered. You should arrange to have this equipment installed on the girls' building as soon as the work can be completed.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. Chas. Belanger, S. J.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Spanish, Ont.
