January 22, 1926.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

The Indian Residential School at Spanish, Ont., is a church-owned institution with a pupilage of 224. During the past few months, the management made arrangements to light the buildings by electricity. A Delco unit was installed in each of the boys' and girls' wings and the buildings were wired and fixtures installed.

This institution has received very little assistance from the Department, other than the per capita grant, since it was opened in 1915. This year, $8,000 was voted for repairs and replacements at Spanish and only some $80 has been expended. I wish to recommend that the management be reimbursed to the extent of $176.34 for their costs in connection with the electric light, which was a much needed improvement, and which minimizes the danger from fire.

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.
January 22, 1926.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

The Indian Residential School at Spanish, Ont., is a church-owned institution with a pupilage of 224. During the past few months, the management made arrangements to light the buildings by electricity. A Delco unit was installed in each of the boys' and girls' wings and the buildings were wired and fixtures installed.

This institution has received very little assistance from the Department, other than the per capita grant, since it was opened in 1913. This year, $2,000 was voted for repairs and replacements at Spanish and only some $80 has been expended. I wish to recommend that the management be reimbursed to the extent of $1774.94 for their costs in connection with the electric light, which was a much needed improvement and which minimizes the danger from fire.

Deputy Superintendent General.

APPROVED:

Superintendent General

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 1)
Ottawa, January 29, 1926.

Dear Father Guy:

I am pleased to inform you that the Honourable Mr. Stewart has authorised the reimbursement of the management at the Spanish Indian Residential School for a portion of their expenses in connection with the installation of the electric light. I am enclosing copies of the accounts in question. You will note that the total of our assistance is $1774.94. A cheque for this amount will be directed to the Rev. Principal in a few days.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. Jos. Guy, O.M.I.,
University of Ottawa,
Ottawa, Ont.

Ottawa, February 8th, 1926.

Sir,

This Department has a large Indian Residential School at Spanish, Ont. The site of the School is near the mouth of the Spanish River and the School authorities make considerable use of boats and consequently require a channel to their boat-house. We understand that owing to various reasons this channel has become blocked and if it remains so it will necessitate the school authorities moving their wharf a considerable distance from the school.

The Reverend Principal informs us that if a channel about ½ mile long, 30 feet wide and 6 feet deep, all in sand, were dredged it would not be necessary for them to move their wharf. He further states that he has already discussed the matter of dredging with your Agent Mr. Fuller at SaultSte. Marie.

This Department would be pleased if you would give the above matter careful consideration and if possible arrange for the dredging desired by the Principal.

Any correspondence to the Principal of the school should be addressed - Reverend Charles Belanger, S.J., Principal, Indian Residential School, Spanish, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean

S.E. O'Brien, Esq.,
Secretary,
Department of Public Works,
OTTAWA.

SPECIFICATIONS
of
CENTRAL HEATING PLANT

INDIAN BOYS' & GIRLS' SCHOOL
Spanish.......................... Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 1)
The Condition of the Power and Heating Apparatus at the present time and the suggested Changes.

The boilers at present are not the right type. They are Cast-Iron sectional, good for Coal, but very badly suited for wood in comparison with the return horizontal tubular boilers.

There are three boilers of this Cast-Iron type in the Girls' Building and two in the Boys' which means that for heating purposes only, regardless of heating domestic water or generating steam to operate the Laundry, they are operating five fires and also a hot air furnace in the chapel.

Owing to the way the boilers are installed in the Boys' building it is necessary to light both of the boilers to heat the entire building, even the mildest weather.

Regarding the operation of the Laundry in the Girls' Building, they are not able to properly utilize the Laundry Equipment owing to the fact that the Boiler is entirely too small to operate the engine which runs the machinery and the drying room. Owing to this it is impossible to properly ventilate the dryer during the drying operation; the bad results from this are showing on the clothes.

The hot water used for Laundry purposes and for domestic use in general is heated with a Jacket Heater connected to a 100 gal. storage tank; both the Jacket Heater and the storage tank are a great deal too small for the work they have to do; the result is that the heater runs with all the drafts open to try heating enough water, which is impossible for it to do. Coal is burned in this Heater at quite a loss.

It will be seen by the above stated facts that the condition of the hot water heating, the domestic water heating and the steam power plant at these buildings are in a very bad condition.
1---That the right type of boilers are not used.
2---That the Steam and Domestic Heating Equipment are not near large enough.
3---The boilers in the Boys' building are in separate units.
4---That 2 Sections of the boilers are defective. One section in No 3 Boiler in the Girls' building and one in No 2 Boiler in the Boys'.

Such is the condition of the plant in the present time, and it has caused a great deal of trouble this last winter.

To remedy the above, the following is suggested:

Install a Central Steam Plant in a separate building and generate enough steam to heat the two buildings and also to supply the Laundry and Domestic hot water, which is essential to good results and economical operation in a Laundry.

In the new plant there will be but one fire used during the greater portion of the heating season; in the very severe weather it would be necessary to light the second boiler but the greater portion of the time one will suffice in place of eight as now required. It is quite readily seen the savings which will occur both in operation and fuel with this installation and furthermore it will be possible at any time to install a small Steam Driven Generating Set to provide enough power for Light and Laundry purposes and use the exhaust steam for heating; the plans have been drawn with this in view.

The plan shows three boilers; the two large boilers are for winter use, one acting as an auxiliary to the other; the small boiler for the Laundry work in the summer.
The boilers are to be of H.R.T. type, brick set, hung front and rear, of dimensions as shown on plan; to be complete with all necessary trimming including twin safety valves, blow off valves, flue cleanout doors; Cast-Iron Fronts; shaking grates; Cyclone or equal and are to be constructed for a working pressure of a hundred pounds in accordance with the Ontario Boiler Act for operation in Ontario.

The two large boilers are to be hung as shown on plan from one cross steel beam with necessary upright supports. The small boiler to be independently erected in a similar manner and all to comply with the Ontario Boiler Act.

Plans of brick setting are to be furnished with the boilers; all internal walls from three courses below the grates are to be lined with the approved fire bricks dipped in fire clay, the external walls will be built of cement or clay brick as approved, laid in cement mortar.

The smoke breeching is to be constructed of 14 gage sheet steel shaped as shown on plan and to be stiffened with necessary angles and T irons. Cleanout sliding doors of ample size to be placed where shown.

This pump is to be of sufficient capacity to handle all the return condensation from the entire plant; it is to be duplex, brass lined with bronze covered pistons, rods fitted with a mechanical lubricator; the pump is to be mounted on a Cast-Iron base and connected to a Cast-Iron receiving tank three ft. by 24 inches and is to be automatic; it is to be for high pressure as well, as low pressure work and is to operate anywhere between 5 to 100 lbs.
CONVERTERS

There are to be 2 steam converters each one of sufficient capacity to heat 7000 sq. ft. of direct hot water radiation independent of mains. Shell to be Cast-Iron or steel with floating heads and U tubes. Tubes to be brass. Simms, Kelly or Many or equal. Capacity to be based on steam at 5% lbs. pressure. Each heater is to be furnished with a low pressure steam trap; this trap is to discharge into a main return and may be Squiers, Wright, Bundy or equal.

PRESSURE REDUCING VALVES

Pressure reducing valves to be as shown on plans and of sizes indicated 2½ in. and over to be flanged; 2 in. and under to be screwed. Mason, Darling Bros., Crane or equal.

BACK PRESSURE VALVES

Back pressure valves are to be placed on the exhaust from the engine in the Laundry and on the exhaust on the return pump in the boiler room, 2½ in. on the engine and 2 in. on the pump Iron body screwed No 384 Crane catalogue or equal.

OIL SEPARATORS

Oil separators to be placed on exhaust from pump and engine 2½ in. and 2 in. Crane Cat. No 01 or equal,

Drip traps of ample capacity are to be placed on the steam main leaving building on the returns from the Laundry machinery and dryer and are to be Bundy, Darling, Crane or equal.

Discharge of all traps are to be connected to main return line.
STEEL TANKS

To save the expense of excavating and to secure proper drainage it is the intention to install a steel tank to set the pump and receiver in, to secure gravity return to same. This tank is to be made of 1/2 in. steel plate riveted and sealed tight and is to have a 3 in. angle iron riveted on top; this angle iron is to be drilled at corners for anchor bolts 1/2 in. which are to be furnished with tank. This tank is to be set in position as shown on plan, previous to the installation of the concrete floor in the pump room.

DOMESTIC HEATER FOR LAUNDRY

A 500 gal. storage tank and heater is to be installed in the Laundry, horizontal type, steel shell, with brass tubes, Simms, Kelly, Darling Bros., or equal, with Powers or Sarco Automatic temperature control. This tank is to have a safety valve 1/2 in. dia. set at 75 lbs. also a mercury thermometer. This heater is to be of ample capacity to heat 500 gal. of water per hour from 45 degrees to 180 with steam at 5 lb. pressure and is to be connected to the exhaust of the engine in the Laundry room, also to leave steam main and to the present Jacket heater.

PIPING & WORK IN GENERAL

The Cast-Iron boilers in the boys' building (3) to be removed and the mains and returns to be grouped together in two headers. These headers are each to have an 8 in. branch for connection to converter, with valves on same. The valves on the mains are to be left as at present. Run the necessary steam and returns from boiler room and connect to converter as shown on details.

No 3 boiler in the girls' building is to be removed and the present header arranged to provide an 8 in. outlet for connection for Converters. Install the necessary steam and return piping to Laundry Engine Room.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
The piping to the dryer and other laundry equipment will also start from the Laundry engine room where the duct from the central heating plant enters building.

The piping in general is to be run as shown on the plan unless otherwise ordered and is to be of the sizes marked. All pipe is to be Standard Steel pipe except that in the duct which is to be extra heavy. All fittings are to be Standard Cast-Iron, screwed up to and including 2 in. and flanged 2½ in. and over unless otherwise ordered.

Care is to be taken regarding expansion. Pipes are to be left free from walls, etc.

Expansion joints are to be placed on steam and return lines in duct as marked on plans and to be Ross or Crane with anchorage saddle base and 8 in. traversed.

Valves are to be gate valves throughout. Standard Jenkins or Crane. 2 in. and under, brass screwed... 2½ in. and over iron bodied flanged.

The piping in the duct steam and return only, are to be covered. The steam with magnesia covering 1 in. thick. The return with Asbestocel covering 1 in. thick. This covering when completed is to be covered with 8 oz. duck, sawed on and painted 2 coats of lead and oil paint.
and then covered with 2 ply ready roofing securely fastened on
with galvanized iron bands as directed. The balance of the
piping will not be covered at present.

The domestic heater in the Laundry, the main smoke breeching
in the boiler's room and the 2 Converters are to be covered as
follows: Wire sheet galvanized iron angles to the surfaces to
allow at least 1 in. air space. To the angles attached securely,
the wire lath cover with 1½ thick Asbestos trowl smooth and
covered with 8 oz. duck, sewed and painted 2 coats.

All safety valves on boilers are to be piped to the outside.

Hangers are to be placed on piping where required or directed
to prevent sagging or trapping and are to be similar in style
to Crane R-S-SS-T. or others as approved.

Sleeves with clearance of 1 in. all around are to be installed
where pipes pass through walls or ceilings.

Steam connection are to be so left at Converters that automatic
temperature control may be installed at some future date.

All iron work and piping not covered with Asbestos
is to be given 2 coats of black asphaltum paint.

The entire equipment is to be installed in the most workman-
like manner and carried out as per plans and specifications
unless otherwise ordered and all material will be subject to
the approval of the owner or their representatives.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 1)
Connect to the drain outside of building, a 4 in. Cast-Iron medium weight, soil line; run the same into boiler room at sufficient depth below the boiler room floor to drain same. This drain is also to be run to the mouth of the duct and arranged there as directed. Branches are to be left on this drain for the blow offs of the boilers and for a sink connection where directed. The water supply for the boilers etc. will be connected to the present system in the existing buildings at the most convenient place.
EXCAVATING & BACK FILLING

All excavating is to be done to give ample room for the erection of the building; trenches are to be excavated deep enough and wide enough to allow for the work to be installed in a workmanlike manner and all back-fillings are to be thoroughly tamped. Trenches and basements are to be kept free from water during construction.

CONCRETE WORK

All cement in the work is to be 1st. quality Portland cement. Concrete to be mixed 4 to 1 of good clean sand and gravel. Footing and walls are to be of sizes as shown on plans. Form work has to be left 6 days before being removed after the concrete has been poured. The floor of the Delco room is to be reinforced with steel; also the footings for the boilers and chimney; care to be taken with the erection of the form work to have it true and smooth. The whole of the boiler room, pump room and fuel room is to have a concrete floor graded to the traps with 8 in. of broken stone and 4 in. of concrete finished smooth. A depression in this floor is to be left of 4 in. deep and the size of the ash pit under the boilers.

The duct connecting the boiler room with the girls' school is to be carefully graded and to have 18 in. fall from building to building. This duct is to be specially reinforced where it crosses the road; it is to be constructed as per details. Inserts are to be placed in it for hangers. The top is to be made in sections and after all the piping has been tested, covered and inspected, the sections are to be cemented on, and the top is to be waterproofed, with pitch and felt as directed.
BRICK WORK

It is the intention to build the building out of cement brick corresponding in size and colour to the brick used in the present building. The brick work will start approximately 3 ft from the present grade and care is to be taken to tie the two 4 in. walls securely together so as to allow 1½ in. air space.

Sills and lintels will be made to correspond with the present building.

The chimney is to be built with the same kind of brick as mentioned above and in designs and size as shown on plan and is to be lined with fire brick 20 ft. high starting at 1 ft. below the entrance of the breeching. It is also to have a cement cap.

CARPENTER WORK

The doors, windows, and all wood work will be supplied by the owners. These will be erected in a workmanlike manner as shown on plan as directed with all necessary hardware, etc., to make everything complete.

TINSMITHING

The entire roof is to be covered with 4 ply felt on top of which is to be placed a 26 gage galvanized roof standing seam or battened soldered where required.

The entire ceiling of the boiler room will be sheeted with ½ in. sheeting by the carpenter and is to be covered by the tinsmith with very plain metal ceiling. The whole of the above work is to be done in a most workmanlike manner and to the complete satisfaction of the owners.
Provide and install an Underwriter's Fire Door where boiler room passage way connects with main building.

All wood work and the metal ceiling is to receive 3 coats of paint; colours to be approved by owners. Painting is to be done when directed by owners. All glasses to be double thick and particular care is to be taken with the sky light.

The work is to be done in steel conduit; lights are to be placed in the fuel room; 4 in the boiler room; 1 in the pump room and 1 in each of the passage ways. These are to be controlled by switches placed where directed. The mains are to be carried into the Delco room. Lights, switches and sockets will be provided by owners. The moving of the Delco Apparatus from its position to the new building will also be done by the owners.

The entire work of all trades is to be done in the best possible manner both as to material and workmanship and to the entire satisfaction of the owners.

MEMORANDUM

Mr Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

The Jesuit Fathers of Upper Canada in charge of the Indian Residential School at Spanish, beg to submit the following remarks to your kind attention.

The heating system of the large school buildings, always more or less defective from the start; has become so unsatisfactory and expensive, that it is in absolute need of renewal or complete repair. In the cold weather the furnace of the girls' school, worked to its utmost capacity, cannot raise the temperature higher than 600 Fahrenheit. Some sections of the boilers in all furnaces are completely out of order.

The total absence of unit connections makes it necessary to light the eight fires even in mild weather and thus increase enormously the fuel expense.

We have had these conditions examined by some of the best experts in heating systems and they have at once declared that the only economical device would be a Central System that would heat the two school buildings and operate satisfactorily the laundry equipment as well as the electrical generators which your Department has so generously installed, three years ago.

We herewith submit plans and specifications of these experts. As explained in the said plans and specifications the cost of the material for the additional building, boilers, pipes, duct etc for the whole system would be approximately $23,346.00.

As particular circumstances have added to our staff expert craftsmen who can reliably execute the work under whatever supervision you might decide upon, we could take charge of the whole installation provided your Department would supply the material required. We therefore make an official request for said material under conditions above referred to.

We realize that we are asking for a great favor but it is a case of absolute necessity for the welfare of
the Department's wards. We have taken the liberty of making this demand in consideration of the work carried on by us and the heavy expenses incurred by our institution. May we be allowed to mention that since the foundation of our school in 1870 we have always endeavored to serve the Department with devoted fidelity. Amongst other things we would state that we have always gladly accepted whatever number of Iroquois children were sent to us.

Since 1913, we have invested over $240,000.00 in the present buildings and farms at Spanish. With a staff of 16 men and 18 women we are now educating 237 Indian children to the very best advantage of the Indians and the greatest economy for the Department.

Now we understand that the Department is not presently in a position to give us financial help out of this year's estimates but we beg to propose the following plan: We would agree to borrow sufficient money to cover the whole cost and undertake the work. In the course of the next fiscal year when the estimates of the Department would be voted we could present for reimbursement all bills for material duly paid by us.

With keen hopes of a favorable answer, we have the honor, Dear Sir, to remain

Your humble servants,

THE JESUIT FATHERS OF UPPER CANADA

per

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 1)
MEMORANDUM:

With reference to the letter from the Rev. Principal of the Spanish Indian Residential School, I beg to report that I have examined the plans and specifications for a new heating system for these buildings. The present system consists of three hot water boilers in the girls' building and two in the boys', also a boiler for heating the domestic water supply for the building and steam for the laundry. The chapel is heated by a hot air furnace. The main defects in the present system are that the boilers, being cast iron section type, are not suitable for burning wood; that the steam and the domestic heating equipment are not large enough to meet the requirements of the buildings; and that the firing of so many boilers is both uneconomical and unsatisfactory.

In order to remedy the above it is suggested to install a central steam heating plant in a separate building, and generate enough steam to heat the two buildings and also to supply the laundry, and it is proposed to install in this separate building two large fire box return tubular boilers, which are suitable for burning wood as well as coal. The Reverend Principal states that the staff of the school will take charge of the whole installation, providing the Department will supply the materials. They estimate the cost at $23,546.00, and it would appear that this estimate is reasonable, but I cannot state definitely what the cost would be without visiting the school and making a careful examination of the existing system, and checking up the plans for the new work in the buildings.

The Principal states further that since 1915 they have invested over $240,000.00 in the present building and farms at Spanish. They have a staff of 16 men and 18 women, and are now educating 237 Indian children. He states further that if the Department is not in a position to give financial help out of this year's estimates, that they will agree to borrow sufficient money to cover the cost of the work, the amount to be refunded to them next year. They would present bills for all materials used.

[Signature]

If you would draw this matter again to my attention early in the autumn, I would give it further consideration.

Dear Sir,

Would you be kind enough to advise me about a ventilator to be placed in our kitchen. It is one story building attached to a three storey house. The stove is at the end, close to the house.

What kind of ventilator, to have always a draught from any wind. The ventilator should be over the stove I think. The kitchen is 20 ft. long, 18 ft. wide and 12 ft. high.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 1)
Spanish Residential Schools, December 15th 1926

To Mr. Duncan Scott, Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
36 - Ottawa.

Dear Kind Mr. Scott,

Pursuant to the interview which you so kindly gave me, concerning necessary repairs to the very defective Heating System of the Spanish Residential Schools, may I beg you to consider our request for an initial grant (of at least five thousand dollars) that would enable us to begin the work in 1927.

The Girls' School has a debt of $40,000 and the Boys' School still owes $35,000. Under these burdens, it is impossible for us to undertake alone these repairs.

We realize that the Spanish Schools' buildings are not owned by your Department; but we ask to submit that, in practice, we have always endeavored to let you have the full direction of the schools, by yielding faithfully to your desires and suggestions. We trust that this moral ownership will justify you to give us the needed help.

In thanking you sincerely for all past favors, we wish to assure you of our untiring devotion in the future.

Your obedient servants,

The Jesuit Fathers of Upper Canada,

Sr. Eug. A. Caprion, S.J.,
Spanish Ontario.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
December 16, 1926.

Dear Father Papineau:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, with further reference to the central heating plant for the Spanish Indian Residential School. I wish to inform you that your request for a grant of $5,000 for the work has been noted. I shall have an opportunity of discussing the details of our Indian Education Estimates with the Honourable Mr. Stewart in the near future, and, if the item is allowed, you will be advised.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. Eug. A. Papineau, S.J.,
Indian Residential School,
Spanish, Ont.
Ottawa, February 1st, 1927.

Rev. Sir:

The Department is considering the supplying of the number of single school desks required for the use of the junior classroom in the boys' building at the Spanish Indian Residential School. Before placing the order, however, we wish to have the correct sizes of the desks required. It is thought from the sketch plan of the proposed seating arrangements that the following number of each size of desk would be satisfactory:

6 Desks, Pupils 15-18 Yrs.,
24 = 12-14 "
24 = 10-12 "
14 = 7-9 "

This would provide seating accommodation for 68 pupils.

I shall be pleased to hear as soon as possible whether the above number of each size of desk would be satisfactory, and, if not, would like to have your report as to the number of each size you would recommend be furnished.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. Chas. Belanger, S.J.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Spanish, Ont.

Rev. Sir:

I beg to inform you that an order is today being placed with Messrs. E. N. Moyer Co., Ltd., Toronto, to ship addressed to you the number of single school desks, front and rear seats, as stated in the enclosed copy of the order to the above firm. These desks will be delivered F.O.B. Spanish at the aggregate price of $417.54. When they arrive at Spanish, I shall be pleased if you will arrange to have them taken to the school and set up in the junior classroom in the boys' building. They should be set up in accordance with the sketch of the classroom which you forwarded and which is returned herewith for your information.

The above firm have been requested to forward their account to you in triplicate, and upon receipt of the desks, if in good condition, you will be good enough to certify thereon as follows: "Goods received in good condition; prices charged fair and just." You should then send the account to the Department in order that payment can be made.

These desks will provide seating accommodation for 65 pupils, and it is hoped that they will be satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, March 21st, 1927.

Rev. Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 14th instant, relative to supplying a book rail for the teacher's desk which has recently been supplied for the use of the Spanish Indian Residential School, I beg to say that we understood that the desk ordered, which is known as "Teacher's Sanitary Desk, No. 11," and supplied by the E. Ottawa, March 21st, 1927.

Gentlemen:

I have to refer you to our letter of the 25th ultimo, placing an order for the supplying of a teacher's sanitary desk, No. 11, to be shipped to Rev. Chas. Belanger, Spanish, Ont. We have received a communication from this gentleman in which he states that the desk has arrived, but requests that a book rail be supplied to prevent books and papers from falling off the desk. It is shown in your catalogue that this desk has a book rail. If one was not sent with the desk which you forwarded, I shall be pleased to hear whether you can supply same or not.

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the proposed new central heating plant for the Spanish River Indian Residential School on December 16th of last year you wrote the Reverend Eugene Papineau, S.J., as follows:

"I wish to inform you that your request for a grant of $8,000.00 for the work has been noted. I shall have an opportunity of discussing the details of our Indian Education estimates with the Honourable Mr. Stewart in the near future, and if the item is allowed you will be advised."

There does not appear to be any correspondence since that date.

There is an item of $6,000.00 in this year's estimates as a grant towards this work. The estimated cost of the central heating plant is approximately $24,000.00.

Architect.
April 19, 1927.

Dear Father Belanger:

I am pleased to inform you that there is an appropriation of $5,000 for the purpose of making a grant towards the cost of a central heating plant for the Spanish Indian Residential School. If you decide to proceed with this improvement, you should keep receipts, in duplicate, showing the expenditure for both labour and materials. Your application for this grant, or any part of it, should be supported by these receipts.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. Chas. Belanger, B.J.,
Principal

CANADA
April 30th, 1927.

The Honourable Charles Stewart,
Minister of the Interior,
Ottawa, Ont.

Honourable Sir:

I wish to thank you for your letter of April 14th and for the help that your Department is willing to grant the Indian Industrial School at Spanish, for the installation of a central heating plant.

Closer investigation has convinced me that such a plant would cost more than $15,000. Therefore, I have advised the local Superior, Reverend Father Belanger, to have the actual heating plant thoroughly overhauled and repaired. This, I think can be done with satisfactory results for less than $5,000.

The increase of 92 cts. a month per capita for the pupils in residence will hardly solve our financial difficulties, but I wish to assure you, Sir, that we appreciate this token of that good-will we have always met with in the Department of Indian Affairs.

I remain, Honourable Sir,

Very truly yours,

[Signature]

UNITED SHOE MACHINERY COMPANY
OF CANADA, LIMITED
MONTREAL, QUE.

Mr. Russell Ferrier,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ont.

Indian Resident School
Spanish, Ont.

July 26-27

Gentlemen:

We have from time to time had the pleasure of supplying the Resident School at Spanish, with various items of Shoe Findings & Supplies for their Shoemaking Department, and our Mr. Leveille has also called upon them in connection with this business.

From information which we gather we are of the opinion that a Finishing Machine of one of the smaller types could be used to good advantage in the school and would probably be the means of an economic saving as well as giving the pupils the educational advantage of learning the more up-to-date method of handling shoe repair work.

As you are probably aware we have had the privilege of supplying the Federal and Provincial Governments with Shoe Machinery for use in their various institutions - for example the Kingston Penitentiary, the Dorchester Penitentiary Ontario School for the Deaf, Bellville, etc., etc., and in each instance believe our installations are working out entirely satisfactory.

Where shoemaking is done as an institutional economy or as part of the educational work we have found the pupils derive considerable benefit from being taught the Machine as well as the hand work. While not criticizing hand work which we believe is beneficial, we think you will realize this is becoming less and less used in a commercial way, and in order to be able to secure employment in any modern repair shop the operator is versed in the handling of Machine work, which phrase has been considered by the Department of Justice in installing Machinery in the Penitentiaries and by the D.S.C.R. in vocational re-establishment work.

We are taking the liberty of forwarding you under separate cover a copy of our latest Goodyear Welt Shoe Repairing Machinery catalogue which illustrates the various Shoe Repair Outfits we can supply built in our Montreal factory and would be pleased to have you look these over.
If there is other information or details concerning this proposition that we can supply that would be of assistance to you in reaching a decision if you will kindly advise your inquiry will have our careful attention.

Trusting we may have the pleasure of supplying equipment for the School.

Yours very truly

UNITED SHOE MACHINERY CO OF CANADA LTD

[Signature]

O.M. Brooks
SALES DEPT

DK-
2700-D
Indian Residential School
SPANISH, Ont.

Mr. J.J. Sutherland,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

In answer to Mr. Phelan's letter of the twenty-seventh, I wish to say that we have no meter for our sewing machine, figure E, 1036, of this catalogue. This meter is very desirable because of its strength. It is the one best suited to the work in hand, though perhaps somewhat expensive.

The United Shoe Co. informs me that they propose to the Department a finishing machine. Should I dare mark Figure E, 1024?

As for the meter it must, if it is to be useful here, be an electric one. What strength is required in order to have the machine and the shaft operated separately? Measurements will be sent when we know the strength required.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 1)
Ottawa, August 4th, 1927.

Rev. Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 1st instant, relative to shoemaking equipment which you require for the use of the Spanish Indian Residential School, I beg to inform you that we have been informed that the Department of Soldiers' Civil Re-establishment have for disposal in their depot at London, Ont.,

1 Machine, Progressive, Shoe Repair Outfit complete with Landis Stitcher and Motor Electric 3 H.P. Lincoln Electric (local #13).

It is stated that this machine is in fair working order, and we have requested the Government Contracts Supervision Committee to arrange to have this machine shipped to you, freight charges prepaid. You should arrange to accept delivery of this machine when it arrives at Spanish, Ont., and inform the Department promptly when same is received.

It is hoped that this machine will be satisfactory and will serve the purpose for which you require a stitching machine. No doubt, one of the brothers at the school can arrange to have this machine set up and the motor connected.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. Chas. Belanger, S.J.,
Principal, Indian Res. School,
Spanish, Ont.

CANADA
Dear sir,

We have received few days ago the shoe repairers; I regret to have to tell you that we cannot use it, on account of the lack of power. The motor needs 550V 25Cy, and we have only 110V; and all is used in both houses for lights.

The stitching machine is only for soles, what cannot be used for the shoes of our children.

I am really sorry to have to tell those informations, after having taken so much trouble help us; because it is certainly a precious gift, that I appreciate very much.

Thanking you for all what you have done for us.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

N.B. Our electricity is direct current, and the motor received needs alternate or indirect. We would need a sewing machine to sew uppers.
Ottawa, September 10th, 1927.

Reverend Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the shoe repairing outfit recently forwarded to the Spanish Residential School. In reply I beg to say that an official of the Schools Branch will be at Spanish some time this month and he will discuss the matter with you.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 1)
October 27, 1937.

Memorandum:

HONOURABLE CHARLES STEWART,

A year ago, the authorities of the Spanish Indian Residential School were considering a central heating unit for the various buildings. They made representations to this Department concerning assistance, and an item of $5,000 was placed in the Appropriation for the current fiscal year.

The Jesuit Fathers have decided not to proceed with the central heating scheme, but their energies have been directed towards replacements to the lighting system in the main buildings. In the spring, they asked if the appropriation for the school could be changed to meet the present need, and I promised the matter would be brought to your attention in due course. Revising the buildings has cost $8,540.05; a new engine for generating electricity, $590; and an aqueduct for supplying fresh spring water for domestic consumption, $641.07—a total of $9,771.10. Receipts in connection with this expenditure have been forwarded to the Department, and, as funds are available, I wish to recommend that reimbursement be made.

The Spanish Indian Residential School has a pupilage of 285 and, heretofore, practically the entire capital expense has been undertaken by the Jesuit Order.

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.
October 27, 1927.

Memorandum:

HONOURABLE CHARLES STEWART,

A year ago, the authorities of the Spanish Indian Residential School were considering a central heating unit for the various buildings. They made representations to this Department concerning assistance, and an item of $5,000 was placed in the Appropriation for the current fiscal year.

The Jesuit Fathers have decided not to proceed with the central heating scheme, but their energies have been directed towards replacements to the lighting system in the main buildings. In the spring, they asked if the appropriation for the school could be changed to meet the present need, and I promised the matter would be brought to your attention in due course. Rewiring the buildings has cost $2,540.03; a new engine for generating electricity, $690; and an aqueduct for supplying fresh spring water for domestic consumption, $641.07 - a total of $3,871.10. Receipts in connection with this expenditure have been forwarded to the Department, and, as funds are available, I wish to recommend that reimbursement be made.

The Spanish Indian Residential School has a pupilage of 225 and, heretofore, practically the entire capital expense has been undertaken by the Jesuit Order.

Deputy Superintendent General.

November 15th, 1927

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

The Department will remember that some time ago, we placed before you plans for the proposed changing of our heating plant. Some changes are absolutely necessary on account of the new addition added to our school to provide for a better accommodation for the children, principally in the dormitories.

The Department very kindly provided a sum in their estimates this year but, as we were not prepared to go ahead with the heating, they kindly promised consideration for necessary changes that were made in the lighting arrangements.

Enclosed is an estimate received from Crane Limited, which shows that the proposed changes would amount to about $3,101.00. In addition there would be expenses of about $875.00 making a total of a little over $4,000.00.

As the expenses of this new addition are very high for our poor means, I dare once more, to beg from our generous benefactors who showed a great interest in our common work "the betterment of the poor Indians."

I would respectfully request the Department to make provisions for this expenditure in the estimates for the fiscal year 1927-28. I can assure you that, if this is made, your kindness will be greatly appreciated and the improvements that will be effected in the heating arrangements will not only be very beneficial but are absolutely necessary.

Thanking you for past favours and hoping that my present request will meet with approval.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 2)
November 18th, 1927

Sir Dunbar Scott,
Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr Scott,

We are in receipt of your generous gift, for which I heartily thank you, and be assured that I will repeatedly ask God to reward you for such an act of charity, that is: and for the Grant and to allow the change of destination of the amount voted.

This year, comes the absolute necessity of the repair of our very defective heating plant and of adding to it the heating of the new wing, that we are obliged to construct, for better accommodation for the children, principally the dormitories; the whole wing is for the children.

As the expenses of this new addition are very high for our poor means, I dare once more, to beg from our generous benefactors who showed so great interest in our common work—"the betterment of the poor Indians."

I would respectfully request the Department to make provisions for this expenditure in the estimates for the fiscal year 1928-29. I can assure you that, if this is made, your kindness will be greatly appreciated and the improvements that will be effected in the heating arrangements will not only be very beneficial but are absolutely necessary.

I have enclosed in the letter to the Secretary of the Department an estimate from Crane Limited which shows that the proposed changes would amount to about $3,101.00. In addition there would be expenses or about $875.00, making a total of a little over $4,000.00.

Thanking you for past favours and hoping that my present request will meet with approval.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 2)
Ottawa, November 23, 1927.

Gentlemen:

I have to request that you will arrange to supply for the use of the Spanish Indian Residential School, and ship addressed to Rev. Chas. Belanger, S.J., Spanish, Ont., the following fire equipment:

2 Accurate 5 Gal. Pump Tanks, complete with non-freeze charges,
1 - 1½ Qt. Pyrene Extinguisher, complete with charges.

Your account, in duplicate, should be forwarded to Rev. Father Belanger. The price charged should be F.O.B. Spanish, Ont., Government sales tax included. We are informing Father Belanger that the order has been placed with you, and requested, upon receipt of the extinguishers, to certify the account and send it to the Department, when payment will be made.

Yours very truly,

F. H. Paget,
Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

Pyrene Mfg. Co. of Canada Ltd.,
1197-1207 King St. W.,
Toronto, 2, Ont.
Ottawa, November 21, 1927.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant, with reference to the request that the Department give favourable consideration to an expenditure, next year, of $4,000 for the heating alterations, made necessary by the addition you are erecting at the Spanish Indian Residential School. Pursuant to your conversation with Dr. Scott and Mr. Ferrier, I have to inform you that the request will be noted for next year's estimates. Consideration to reimbursing you for the expenditure in connection with the ice house and the new hull for the school boat will be given if you will forward receipts in duplicate. These should be directed to Mr. Ferrier, who will examine them and discuss the question with the Deputy Superintendent General.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. Charles Belanger, S. J.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Spanish, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 2)
Ottawa, November 23rd, 1927.

Gentlemen:

I have to request that you will supply from your nearest branch office one (1) Singer machine for leather stitching, described in your catalogue as "Improved No. 29 - K 51". This machine should be forwarded addressed to Rev. Chas. Belanger, Principal, Indian Residential School, Spanish, Ont.

The account for the machine should be made out in duplicate, and should show the retail price and discount of 50% allowed off the 90 day list price "on which terms purchase is made". We are informing Rev. Father Belanger that the order has been placed with you, and requested, upon receipt of the machine, to certify the account and send it to the Department for payment.

Yours very truly,

F. H. Paget,
Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

Singer Sewing Machine Company,
Bank St., OTTAWA.
Ottawa, November 23rd, 1927.

Rev. Sir:

I beg to inform you that we are today placing an order with the Pyrene Mfg. Co. of Canada, Ltd., Toronto, to ship addressed to you the following fire equipment for the use of the Spanish Indian Residential School:

2 Accurate 5 Gal. Pump Tanks, complete with non-freeze charges,
1 - 1½ Qt. Pyrene Extinguisher, complete with charges.

The above firm have been requested to forward their account, in duplicate, to you covering the cost of this equipment F.O.B. Spanish. Upon receipt of the extinguishers, please certify the account in the usual manner and send it to the Department in order that payment can be made.

I have also to inform you that we are placing an order with the Singer Sewing Machine Company to forward addressed to you 1 leather stitching machine, described in their catalogue as "Improved No. 29 - K 51." This firm have also been requested to ship the machine addressed to you, and to forward their account in duplicate. This account should show the retail price and discount of 50% allowed off the 90 day list price "on which terms purchase is made". When the machine is received, please certify the account in the usual manner and send it to the Department in order that payment can be made. It is hoped that when this machine arrives it will prove satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. Chas. Belanger, S.J.,
Principal, Indian Res. School,
Spanish, Ont.

Dear sir,

I was told some times ago that the Department had no money to provide us with a gasoline motor for the shoe-shop. Today I am told that the Department would send the one proposed by the United Shoe Co if it is called for. Should I dare to ask for it now? Would it not be too abuse of your kindness? We would be certainly very thankfull for this so nice and usefull gift.

Thanking in advance.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Ottawa, December 10, 1927.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, relative to the supplying of a gasoline engine for the shoe shop at the Spanish Indian Residential School.

In reply I beg to say that you may place an order with the United Shoe Machinery Company of Canada, Ltd., Montreal, for the supplying of a 1½ H.P. New gasoline engine of the type described in their catalogue as Fig. E-1052. The Department understands that the cost of this engine is $91.00 F.O.B. Montreal. Please have this firm quote you a price F.O.B. Spanish.

When the engine has been received by you, you should obtain and forward a properly certified account, in duplicate, covering the cost.

The Department hopes that when this engine arrives it will provide the power necessary for the shoe making equipment at this school.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. MacInnes,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. Chas. Belanger, S.J.,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
Spanish, Ont.

January 30, 1928.

Memorandum:

There is an item of $5,000 in the Appropriation for the current year towards the cost of a central heating unit at the Spanish Indian Residential School. The church authorities abandoned the scheme and asked for other improvements to the amount of the Vote. Improvements to plumbing and heating, a new hull for the school launch and smaller items amounting to approximately $4,500 have been allowed.

When the Rev. Father Belanger was in Ottawa in November, he asked that favourable consideration be given in the matter of reimbursement for expenses incurred in the construction of an ice house. Receipts totalling $1,211.94 are now to hand. The materials and freight amount to $653.01 and labour, $558.93.

I wish to recommend that the school authorities be reimbursed for the materials and that they be responsible for the labour, themselves.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, January 30, 1928.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, enclosing receipts in connection with the expenditure on the ice house at the Spanish Indian Residential School.

The Department has already expended approximately $4,575 on improvements to physical equipment at your school this fiscal year. In addition, there has been an expenditure of over $600 for desks, fire fighting equipment, etc. I regret that it will not be possible to give favourable consideration to reimbursing you for the entire costs of the ice house; and the Deputy Superintendent General has directed that you provide the labour. The materials and freight costs amount to $652.01 and a cheque for this will be forwarded to you under separate cover. I am returning the receipts for labour.

Enc.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. Charles Belanger, S. J.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Spanish, Ont.

Dear sir,

Yesterday we fixed the desks you were so kind to give us, as I was not there when they went on in their work and finished them all. The trouble is that they are not the same as those furnished two years ago; then they were all cherry color, the new ones are backs and seats white and the table cherry, so it spoils the good appearance of the class. Could anything be done to have all the same color.

I am sorry to give you this useless trouble. I would have written to the firm, but as the order was from the Department, I thought better to inform you.

Yours truly,

November 21st, 1928.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Attention of Mr. J. D. McLean.

Gentlemen:

Re your file 36-0-5. We have your communication of November 19th with reference to an order for Desks shipped to Spanish, Ont.

We understand now that it was your intention to have all woods finished in cherry. We would explain that the standard finish of practically all Canadian manufacturers is cherry tops, and natural finish backs and seats, and it is necessary to supply any other finish on special order. Unless the quantities are fairly large, this is quite expensive.

The objection to a cherry finish for the backs and seats is the fact that when these become scratched, through time, the marks show more prominently on the cherry than on the natural finish.

We have asked our factory to advise us if they could make this exchange, and as soon as they let us know we will write you further.

Yours very truly,

E. N. Moyer Company Limited,
General Manager.

Dear sir. Would it be too abuse of your kindness than to present again this an estimate of the expenses for the next year, in order to give a better accommodation to the Indian children?

Till now the Department has been so kind, that I am afraid be excessive in our petitions.

These are the things absolutary necessary, I would ask you to take them in consideration:

1. One boiler for the laundry: Taylor-Forbes. $1361.75.
2. 2 sets of batteries: Delco Light $770.00 each. $1540.00
3. 9 fire-hose and fittings: Crane or Taylor. $360.00
4. 58 steps for stairs: Bélanger Co. $2.00 each. $116.00
5. Metallic veneer: Eastern Steel Products Preston. $1206.20
6. Hard wood flooring 1000' $165.00. Evans, Sudbury $1050.00

Total. $5633.95.

These are the principal items.

Thanking in advance for this and many past favours.

Yours very sincerely and obliged,

[Signature]

We would be very obliged if the Department could tell us about better batteries than the Delco. Since three years only and they are completely out of use. Such an expense every three years.
The boiler is for the laundry, as the old one is far too small, it cannot furnish the steam for the dryer, and it has to be repaired having many tubes defective.

Hard wood floor (maple) birch would be cheaper, but it does not last with the heavy use of our children. $9500 is the price of birch.

C.B.S.J.
MEMORANDUM:

Dr. [signature]

You will remember that Father Belanger, principal of the Spanish Indian Residential School, when in Ottawa a few weeks ago, left receipts showing expenditure of over $5,000. for mechanical plant at the boys' school new wing and expenditure of over $2,000. for repairs to the plumbing and laundry equipment at the girls' wing. You instructed me to have this put in order and to bring the matter to your attention again.

There is an item of $4,000. for this purpose in the main estimates for the current fiscal year but, in view of the large expenditure for the new boys' wing, I am recommending reimbursement to the extent of $4,850.99. The papers which are attached to the explanatory voucher are now in order.

[signature]
Supt. of Indian Education.
November 24, 1928.

Memorandum:

HONOURABLE CHARLES STEWART,

A year ago, the Provincial Superior of the Jesuit Order intimated that he was arranging to build, this year, an addition to the boys' wing at the Indian Residential School at Spanish, Ont. He requested that the Department assist by securing an appropriation to cover the cost of the plumbing and heating. I, accordingly, placed an item of $6,000.00 in the Main Estimates for the current fiscal year.

The addition has been completed and receipts have been forwarded to the Department, showing an expenditure of over $5,000.00 for mechanical plant. In view of the heavy expense undertaken by the Order at this school, I wish to recommend that the Department make reimbursement to the extent of $4,850.99. The papers showing an expenditure of this amount are in order and the funds are now available in the Appropriation for Indian Education.

Duncan C. Scott
November 26th, 1928.

Reverend Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 14th instant, I have to inform you that we are today placing an order with the Pyrene Manufacturing Company of Canada, Limited, Toronto, to ship, addressed to you, 5 - 5 gallon pump tank fire extinguishers, complete with non-freeze charges, for the use of the Spanish Indian Residential School.

We are also placing an order with the LaFrance Fire Engine & Foamite, Ltd., Montreal, to forward three recharges for the Foamite fire extinguishers.

The above firms have been requested to forward their accounts, in duplicates, to you. When the supplies have been received, please certify these accounts in the usual manner and send them to the Department in order that payment can be made.

When the new extinguishers are received, they should be placed at strategic points throughout the addition to the building. You should also arrange to have the recharges placed in the Foamite extinguishers.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Reverend Sir:

Mr. Phelan's report on his recent visit to the Spanish Residential School has been received. The Department considers that the school management should make an immediate effort to improve the means of access to the present fire escape on the boys' building.

It would also appear advisable to arrange for the erection of an additional fire escape, both on the boys' building and on the girls' school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Reverend Sir,

With reference to a voucher dated the 23rd November, 1928, for $4550.99, which you submitted to the Department and which was paid on the 5th December by cheque No. 3159, I beg to point out that there was an item therein of $3299.38, the amount of a receipted account submitted from Taylor-Forbes Company, Limited, of Guelph, which account is dated the 26th November, 1928. Dear sir,

While getting our boat ready for the summer, the idea came to me of what should be done in case of fire. As these boats, that is the tug and the tow-boat, are to carry our children or to picnic or to go home, it would be prudent to provide for fire protection.

Would it be, to abuse of the kindness of the Department to ask for two fire-guns small size, one for each boat?

Thanking you in advance for this one and past favours.

Yours truly,
C. Bélanger S.J.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Dear sir,

We are in the necessity of buying a new tow-boat for the transportation of the children, or for picnics, or for holidays. As our bank book does not seem to enjoy such an expense, having only to show poor figures nearly all the time, may we trust in the kindness of the Department to help us out? The boat that we have now is 20 years old, and so does not want to go to any new operation, or in the ribs, or on the nose. He claims that he did enough, and we must give his eternal rest.

I do not think that we can have anything for less than $6, or $700.00. We need a safe boat so that the children are not exposed in time of storms.

Hoping that this new begging will not bother you too much, and thanking you in advance.

I remain,

Yours very sincerely grateful,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 2)
Ottawa, August 7, 1929.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, with reference to replacing the boat at the Spanish Indian Residential School. I understand that this is the boat that it towed behind the launch for transporting children.

In reply I am pleased to state that the Department will provide the materials necessary for this boat, and you may forward an account, in duplicate, in favour of the firm supplying the lumber, etc. I take it for granted that not more than $400 will be needed for the materials. The school is expected to provide the labour without cost to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. Chas. Belanger, S.J.,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
Spanish, Ont.

The Secretary,
Dept. Of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear sir,

I come and thank you for the nice cheque you obtain for us. I was told all the trouble you had to go through to have these vouchers in order, so that they be accepted. Be assured that every day I pray to God give you according your great spirit of charity.

Yours very sincerely and grateful.

C. Bélanger

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 2)
Indian Residential School
SPANISH, Ont.

The Secretary.
Dept. of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.

Dear sir,

In order to give always better accommodation to the children that are intrusted to our care, we have to go to very great expenses. So this year, the whole heating system of the girl's school has to be repaid. Already over $1500 has been paid for pipes and one new furnace, to replace an old one that is completely out of order, and $800 has to be paid for new added radiators.

As you are aware, our means are very small to face such a great expense. Would it be to abuse of the kindness of the Department, than to ask help to defray these debts? You may be assured that every penny received is strictly employed for these two schools.

Knowing your past generosity towards our institutions, I am assured that you will take this petition into consideration.

Thanking you in advance.

C. Belanger

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 2)
Ottawa, September 4, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, with reference to expenses in connection with the heating plant at the Spanish Indian Residential School. I note that the improvements have cost $2,300. I am pleased to state that approximately $500 is still available for capital expenditure at your school, and, if you will let me have receipts, in duplicate, showing expenditure to this amount, a cheque for reimbursement will be directed to you.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. Charles Belanger, S. J.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Spanish, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 2)
The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear sir,

As the amount of the money that can dispose the Department in favour of our schools is very limited, I would ask you to send me back the bills forwarded for the expenses of the trip to Wikwemikong and fro, if the money has to be taken from the $500 left in our favour, and so also to put aside the requisition of the two sewing machines. These two items could be called for, in the future, but the payment of the heating plan cannot be postponed.

Thanking you for all yours generous favours.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

The Secretary.

Dept. of Indian Affairs.

Ottawa.

Dear sir,

We would be very grateful if the Department be kind enough to take into consideration the following estimate in favour of our institutions of Spanish.

1. Boys school:
   a. A new boat $750. Necessary for the transportation of the children to and from the school for holidays, and also for holiday's pic-nics, it is to be hauled by the gasoline launch. The Department kindly promised by official letter of the 7th Aug., 1929 $400. for the purchase of this boat, but as I could not secure one for that price, I beg the Department, if possible, to allow the whole amount required, $750.

   Also one row boat, to provide for accidents, on the trip, being hauled also by the same launch, $30.00.

   b. An auxiliary furnace and boiler to supply hot water for baths $450. This is necessary to provide for hot water for baths, at any time of the year.

2. Girls school:

   Heating plant repaired and one new furnace, and work. All
All these repairs were absolutely necessary. The proximate amount is $4300.

Thanking you in advance for this great favour and the past one.

Yours very sincerely, and obliged.

[Signature]

Very Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, enclosing a communication from the Rev. Principal of the Spanish Indian Residential School, with reference to improvements for next year. The Department will ask Parliament to provide funds for a new boiler and hot water equipment at the Boys' School.

The request to assist the school authorities with replacement to the heating plant at the Girls' School reaches the Department a little late, as our Estimates have been under consideration for some time. Ottawa, June 11, 1930.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, requesting that two fire alarm bells be installed in the dormitories and one dozen mattresses be supplied for the use of the Spanish Indian Residential School.

In connection with the fire alarm bells, I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase of two bells of the size and type considered by you to be satisfactory to meet the purpose for which they are required. It is understood that you will have these bells installed in the dormitories without expense to the Department. After you have purchased the bells, you should obtain an account, in duplicate, which you should certify in the usual manner and send to the Department for payment.

Relative to the twelve mattresses of the sizes required, I have to say that we are today placing an order with Simons, Limited, Montreal, to forward same addressed to you. The above firm will also forward their account covering the cost of these mattresses. When they are received at the school, if in good condition, you should certify the account in the usual manner and send it to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Dear sir,

I was advised few years ago by one of your Department, who seemed to pity on the poor appearance of our study hall, to ask for new desks. I did not dare to do it, as we had so much to ask for. And so I postponed until today. As we have to organize for three classes, we have to change the position of the desks, what makes us needy of other size desks. At the same time I enclosed what we would need for our study hall.

No 2. Rear ends: 18.
" 2. Desks 46.
" 3. Fronts. II.
" 3. Desks. 51.
" 4. Fronts. 9.

It is quite a number after all you have been so kind to give us already.

Our desks are all brown ones.

If the Department decides to grant this favour, I would ask to hurry the shipment, so that we get everything ready for the

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 2)
Ottawa, August 6th, 1930.

Reverend Sir,

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo, with reference to the boys' study hall at the Spanish Indian Residential School. To purchase the number of desks which you would need for this purpose would mean nearly $1,000 expenditure. Could not strong tables and benches be constructed if the Department allowed the material? These would be just as suitable for study purposes as desks and would be better for games, etc. Please give this your consideration and let me have a further letter from you.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 2)
Dear Mr. MacKenzie,

I am in receipt of your kind letter of the 6th inst., showing your great desire to comply with the heavy requisition of desks I have made few days ago. I knew that the cost would be high, this was the reason of my omitting it, since years. I am sorry to have to say that tables would not suit us at all. I have homemade desks only double, and nevertheless, I find great inconvenience in them.

I understand very well the objection of the Department, after the reception of the last generous cheque.

What would you think, if I postpone (as in fact I postponed it) the construction of the new boat. In the letter of the Department 21st Nov. 1929, was allowed a certain amount for the construction of the said boat. I was asked by the constructors $1,000. $500 etc. So, could not this money be apply for the desks?

Now if there are too many inconveniences, we will simply continue with the old ones, that are yet good for some time, and when the favorable wind comes, we will lunch a new petition.

So do not hesitate to tell me no, because you may be assured that I will not be less grateful for all that was done for us in the past.

Thanking you in advance for your great kindness.

I remain,

[Signature]

Reverend Sir,

I have your letter of the 8th instant, relative to your request to be supplied with desks for the boys' study hall at the Spanish Indian Residential School. In this connection I have to say that our funds for the present fiscal year are extremely limited and I regret that it will not be possible to provide the expenditure required in supplying the desks asked for. An item is being noted for our estimates for the next fiscal year to cover the cost of new desks.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sirs,

Owing to the different dispositions of the desks in the class rooms and study hall, we have some left, that perhaps the Department would be able to dispose of some place else.

We have: rears (2 only no 5), front, 3 only no. 2, and 4 only no 5, desks.

If the Department finds place for them, we will crate them and have them shipped at destination. Perhaps F. Papineau would need them.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 2)
Ottawa, October 2, 1930.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 1st instant informing the Department that you have for disposal at the Spanish Indian Residential School a number of desks and front and rear seats, and stating that, if the Department can use same, you will have them crated and shipped where required.

In reply I have to say that at the present time the Department is not aware as to where this extra seating accommodation is required. I shall be pleased if you will, at your earliest opportunity, consult Rev. Father Papineau who may be able to place them in some of the Indian day schools in which he is interested. If he requires these desks, the Department would pay the cost of shipping them upon receipt of an account, in duplicate, from you, together with a receipt attached for the shipping charges paid.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. Chas. Belanger, S.J.,
Principal, Indian Res. School,
Spanish, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 2)
October 23, 1930.

The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Gentlemen:

We have an order from the Indian Residential School, Spanish, Ont. Would you please advise us if this school is in connection with your Department.

We are interested from a credit standpoint, and are anxious to know who is responsible for the payment of any order which we may ship to this school.

Yours truly,

BEARDMORE LEATHERS LIMITED.

per

HT/H

TANNERS IN CANADA SINCE 1844.
Ottawa, October 25, 1930.

Gentlemen:

In reply to your letter of the 23rd instant, I beg to say that the Indian residential school at Spanish, Ont., is conducted by the Jesuit Order in conjunction with the Department of Indian Affairs. The Reverend Principal of this school is responsible for payment of all accounts, and you may have no hesitation in filling any orders that you receive from the Spanish School.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary

Hearldmore Leathers Limited,
37 Front St. E.,
Toronto 2, Ont.
Water Supply:

The water supply for the Spanish School is obtained from a spring situated two hundred yards back of the school. From this spring the water runs to reservoirs situated near the respective schools and, from these reservoirs, the water is pumped by windmills to the tanks on the top floor of each building. Father Howitt stated that, during the past month, a number of the boys have, apparently, not been as well as could be expected and he rather suspected the water. As a result, he arranged with the Ontario Provincial Health Officer residing at Blind River to test the water. He advised Father Howitt that the water was not as good as it should be, although he did not actually condemn it. He stated that, in his consideration, the water in the reservoirs was becoming slightly contaminated by surface water. Another sample of water had just been sent and Father Howitt stated that, in the event of it not being an improvement on the previous sample, he would advise the Department.

I had an opportunity of seeing both the boys and girls at meal time and found that both were receiving good food in ample quantity.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
MEMO:

Dr. Scott,

In the main estimates for the current fiscal year there were provided items for a boat and to assist with heating alterations at the Spanish Indian Residential School. $3,780.00 was the total provided.

Approximately $800.00 has already been expended this year at this school and there is now at hand a statement supported with receipts showing an expenditure in connection with the boat of $850.00 and in connection with the heating alterations approximately $4,400.00.

As our appropriation is nearly exhausted it will be necessary to limit our grant toward these improvements as far as possible and I wish to recommend that the school be reimbursed for the boat ($850.00) and for heating alterations $1882.74.

Supt. of Indian Education.

We beg to advise you that OUR BUSINESS YEAR ENDS DECEMBER 31ST., at which time we close our books.

It is extremely desirable that all outstanding accounts should be satisfactorily adjusted before that time and we ask your assistance in this respect.

To those whose accounts are of recent date, we simply suggest the convenience to us of having settlement before stock taking.

We feel quite confident that you will comply with our request for which we thank you in advance.

Madam:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th instant, addressed to Mr. Phelan, of this Department, requesting to be supplied with refills for three Foamite fire extinguishers. In this connection I have to inform you that the Department is today placing an order with Lafrance Fire Engine & Foamite Limited, Toronto, to forward, charges prepaid, addressed to you, chemical refills for 3 - 2½ gallon Foamite fire extinguishers. The above firm have been requested to submit to you their account, in duplicate, covering the cost of these refills, f.o.b. Spanish. Upon receipt of these supplies, you should certify on the account "Goods received - prices charged fair and just" and forward same to the Department for payment.

When the refills arrive, please arrange to have them installed in the extinguishers. You should see that these extinguishers are in good condition and ready for immediate use.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 2)
June 29, 1951.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

A steel stair fire escape is required on the girls' building at the Spanish Indian Residential School. Please let me have the name of some competent firm in Sudbury or Sault Ste. Marie, to whom the installation could be offered. The Spanish School is in the federal district of Algoma East.

Duncan C. Scott
Ottawa, June 29, 1951.

Reverend Sir:

Pursuant to Mr. Ferrier's visit to the Spanish Indian Residential School, I have now to inform you that the Department will allow a grant of an amount not exceeding $300 for the purchase of piping with which to make an extra fire escape for the boys' building. It is understood that you will secure second hand piping, if possible, but the Department relies on you to make whatever arrangements you can as soon as possible. A properly certified account, in duplicate, for the materials, should be forwarded. You may also incur an expenditure of $800 for piping and other materials for the change in the water supply system. In due course, a certified account, in duplicate, in this connection, also, should be forwarded to Ottawa for payment.

The Department is arranging to send twelve 6 ft. beds for the girls' dormitory and you will receive an additional letter in this connection. Please inform Miss Bennet. I am also arranging for four 5-gallon fire extinguishers, to be sent to the school - two for the girls' attic and two for the attic in the boys' building. You will receive a letter in this connection at a later date. You may inform Miss Bennet that she will receive a letter in a few days with reference to the steel stair fire escape that is required at the Girls' School.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. James Howitt, S. J.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

With further reference to my memorandum of the 29th ultimo and to phone conversation, I have to inform you that the steel stair fire escape required for the girls' building at the Spanish Indian Residential School will cost approximately $750, installed. The firm given the installation will have to supply the equipment, after first determining just what is required.

I may say that the need for this fire escape was noted by Mr. Perrier, upon the occasion of his recent visit to Spanish. Funds have not been provided for the purpose, and he arranged with the Church authorities to finance it at the present time and to present the receipt next year, after an item could be placed in our next Estimates. When your office gives us the name of a firm, it will be passed on to the Church authorities, who will make the best possible financial arrangements.

As I stated in my former memorandum, the school is in the federal district of Algoma East, and, no doubt, a competent firm can be found in either Sudbury or Sault Ste. Marie.

Duncan C. Scott

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6218, file 471-5, part 2)

MR. BUSKARD,

With further reference to my memorandum of the 29th ultimo and to phone conversation, I have to inform you that the steel stair fire escape required for the girls' building at the Spanish Indian Residential School will cost approximately $750, installed. The firm given the installation will have to supply the equipment, after first determining just what is required.

I may say that the need for this fire escape was noted by Mr. Ferrier, upon the occasion of his recent visit to Spanish. Funds have not been provided for the purpose, and he arranged with the Church authorities to finance it at the present time and to present the receipt next year, after an item could be placed in our next Estimates. When your office gives us the name of a firm, it will be passed on to the Church authorities, who will make the best possible financial arrangements.

As I stated in my former memorandum, the school is in the federal district of Algoma East, and, no doubt, a competent firm can be found in either Sudbury or Sault Ste. Marie.

[Signature]

Department of Indian Affairs;

Gentlemen:

On the occasion of his visit last summer Mr. Ferrier insisted on the need of fire-escapes and urged their erection promising immediate reimbursement to the extent of $300.

We have built them in the places indicated by Mr. Ferrier, one in the front and one in the rear of the building to serve children in the infirmary now on the third floor and also for faculty members who may be there.

Each fire-escape consists of two balconies and slide-pipes as those used by firemen in their stations. The balconies are made of pipe bent and welded in place.

Before having the welding done I asked quotations from a local garage man who has a welding outfit. He wanted 25cts per weld of which there are 180 i.e. $45.00. The four platforms i.e. cutting, drilling, welding the iron plate etc was estimated at $15.00 each.

Instead of paying this sum of $105.00 I thought it better to buy an outfit at the special rate the Canadian Liquid Air Co extends to schools and thus have the added advantage of teaching the boys something of this trade.

Bills for the amount which I would like refunded are enclosed. Sincerely,

J. Howitt.

Dear Sir,

I am sorry to be obliged again to trouble you concerning the refills for the two 5 gallon fire-extinguishers.

The chemicals sent by the Lafrance Fire Engine & Foamite Co. is composed of two ingredients, each to be put in a separate chamber. As the extinguishers we have are with only one chamber we cannot use the chemicals sent.

Besides as the extinguishers are to be kept in the attic it would be advisable to get the Accurate "Freeze Proof" recommended by the manufacturer on the extinguishers.

The extinguishers are from the Pyrene Manufacturing Co., Toronto. Should the chemicals from the Lafrance Fire and Foamite Co. be returned? They are of no use to us.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
